story:
Adventures: Helping the Homeless

That's what Super Ewan calls his time helping those in need. Super Ewan's goal is to provide the basic necessities to help his Super Friends find relief from homelessness. This campaign will allow him to distribute more food, water, clothing and toiletries as well as executing extra projects such his Thanksgiving Dinner Drop-Off and Hope for the Holidays Party for children in need.

Adventure is defined as; participation in bold or exciting undertakings, uncertain of the outcome. I'd like to ask you to join me on this adventure by supporting my Indiegogo campaign.
 

Who is Super Ewan?

Hi, I'm Ewan and I'm 10 years old, When I was 7, I started  Super Ewan, Inc. a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that brings help and hope to the homeless and families in need throughout Metro Detroit. Over the past 3 years I have helped thousands of men, women and children through my twice monthly adventures (distributions). Serving over 5500 lunches, delivering over 6000 lbs of food, 2 tons of clothing, toiletries and just the basic necessities everyone needs.

I'm starting this Indiegogo campaign for one simple reason, the opportunity to do more! Bring more help, give more hope and change more lives. It's so important to show those in need that someone cares, that someone is concerned for their well being and that they matter.

That's what our adventures are all about and together with your support, we can make great things happen!


 

What We Need to Change Lives

My target goal for this campaign is $15,000, any more would be Super!  Naturally, I would love to exceed my goal of $15,000 to be able to help more but reaching it would be awesome!

Reaching our goal would allow us to;

  • Start providing warm nutritional meals at our adventures.
  • Purchase much needed socks/shoes for those in need.
  • Purchase coats/hats/gloves to distribute during the winter months.
  • Offset the cost of our Thanksgiving Dinner Drop-Off and Hope for the Holidays Party.

Exceeding our goal would allow us to;

  • Purchase a van so we can distribute more.
  • Maintain and Insure the van.


​The Impact

It's important for young people to contribute to changing the world and making a difference. Since starting Super Ewan, Inc., I've tried to do just that. Getting friends to help during adventures shows them that they can be a part of positive change.



Through my work with helping those in need, I have been honored to have been selected for local and national awards. I've also had the privilege of appearing on local and national news outlets.

  • 2015 White House Student Film Festival: The Impact of Giving Back
  • 2016 Ernst & Young Youth Entrepreneur of the Year
  • 2017 Prudential Spirit of Community Awards: State of Michigan Honoree
  • People Magazine Online: Meet Super Ewan.
  • Today Show Online: 9-Year-Old superhero helps feed and clothe Detroit's homeless.
  • The Detroit News: 'Super Ewan' helps the homeless in Detroit.
  • CNN's Erin Burnett Out Front: 'Super Ewan' Come to the Rescue of Detroit's Homeless.
  • Documentary Film: Look To The Sky by Documentary Flimmaker Brett Culp

I don't do this for the recognition what-so-ever. The way I look at publicity is this and it's pretty simple, the more people know about my cause, the more people give, the more lives we can change.






 

Super Ewan is an "Imagine If, With Jif" Finalist!

Jif® Peanut Butter knows there is potential and optimism to be found in small things—moments and ideas that, one by one, reinforce our belief in ourselves and in the possibilities that lie ahead. That’s why this year, Jif Peanut Butter is helping spread a little more love in the world through the “Imagine If, With Jif” program to help fuel and nourish the potential of the next generation.

Jif in partnership with Indiegogo, has funded three kids’ positive and impactful entrepreneurial ideas to build a better future for all including Super Ewan.  Super Ewan received $10K from Jif to kick start his official crowdfunding page in November. Jif congratulates Super Ewan on making his big dreams for a better world come true!

In January 2018, Jif will award one grand prize winner with the most successful and impactful crowdfunding project an additional $20K to help make their idea a reality. More information at Jif.com/Imagine-If.
 

Superhero Team

Super Ewan, Inc. is a small yet highly motivated non-profit organization determined to make a big impact on peoples lives. This is us!









Social Media Shout Out                                           Super Ewan Decal
$5 for a shout out from a Super Hero                           $10 and you can stick it anywhere


Super Ewan Backpack                                              Super Shout Out Plus
$25 it's Super Red and Super Awesome!                    $50 Decal, Backpack and Video Shout Out


Personalized Superhero Cape                                 Hero For A Day
$100 and you can be a Superhero like me                  $500 everything and join on an Adventure


Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute, but you can still help:

  • Spread the word about this campaign with friends, co-workers and family.
  • Please share my campaign by using the Social Media Icons at the top.
  • Click one of the icons below to find out more about Super Ewan, Inc.


 

FAQs

Where do your Adventures take place?
Our Adventures are held at Roosevelt Park in Detroit, MI. Roosevelt Park is located in front of the old Michigan Central Train Station in Corktown.

How often do your Adventures take place?
We have Adventures on the second Sunday and the fourth Saturday of each month.

How many homeless do you serve during an Adventure?
We serve between 50-125 people at each Adventure.

What exactly is your Hope for the Holidays Party?
The Hope for the Holidays Party is a special party for 50 underprivileged children. They are provided a meal, visit/picture with Santa, treats and presents.

Can I volunteer with Super Ewan?
Yes, we would love to have you volunteer with us! For more info click here.

Super Ewan, Inc. is a small yet highly motivated non-profit organization determined to make a big impact on peoples lives. This is us!
Social Media Shout Out                                           Super Ewan Decal$5 for a shout out from a Super Hero                           $10 and you can stick it anywhere
Super Ewan Backpack                                              Super Shout Out Plus$25 it's Super Red and Super Awesome!                    $50 Decal, Backpack and Video Shout Out
Personalized Superhero Cape                                 Hero For A Day$100 and you can be a Superhero like me                  $500 everything and join on an Adventure

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute, but you can still help:

Spread the word about this campaign with friends, co-workers and family.
Please share my campaign by using the Social Media Icons at the top.
Click one of the icons below to find out more about Super Ewan, Inc.

 FAQsWhere do your Adventures take place?Our Adventures are held at Roosevelt Park in Detroit, MI. Roosevelt Park is located in front of the old Michigan Central Train Station in Corktown.How often do your Adventures take place?We have Adventures on the second Sunday and the fourth Saturday of each month.How many homeless do you serve during an Adventure?We serve between 50-125 people at each Adventure.What exactly is your Hope for the Holidays Party?The Hope for the Holidays Party is a special party for 50 underprivileged children. They are provided a meal, visit/picture with Santa, treats and presents.Can I volunteer with Super Ewan?Yes, we would love to have you volunteer with us! For more info click here.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of students at Nebraska Wesleyan University who are passionate about justice.  This is our first year as a campus chapter.  Many Americans are not informed about the injustice that the world is facing, and, starting in our community, we would like to start raising awareness about the 30 million people trafficked worldwide.  Indifference is not an option.  This year during the first week of April, we will host a Justice Week on our campus to better inform Wesleyan and the surrounding community of injustice.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1100 as a campus chapter to contribute to the International Justice Mission rescue missions, where a team of trained professionals rescues victims of human slavery and other forms of injustice.  

The entire first week of April, we will be sponsoring a Justice Week on our campus.  We are bringing in speakers from law enforcement and Tiny Hands International (another human trafficking awareness organization).  Through stories, photographs and discussions, we will start conversations about the change that needs to happen and how we can get involved.  

On Wednesday, April 9th, a group of students will be standing for 24 hours.  We are asking supporters to donate a dollar an hour to help us "Stand for Freedom".  

If we do not reach our entire goal, we will still donate all proceeds to the International Justice Mission.  If we exceed our goal, we will utilize these extra funds to further our outreach on campus and in our community.

The Impact

Early this year, through poles and surveys, we found that our campus did not understand the magnitude of this issue.  We plan to change that.  This is a chance for you to contribute to our outreach.  Change cannot occur if we are not informed.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to give financial support, but you can still help us out.  Get informed through the International Justice Mission website and tell your friends.  

Also, God plays a huge role in combating injustice.  Your prayers would be appreciated.

story:
Context: 
Summer 2012, the Parti Quebecois (our provincial separatist party) ramps up its discriminatory anti-English rhetoric, and even suggests preventing people from holding public office unless they have passed French Tests. Premier Marois claims that we have nothing to worry about and that our rights will be respected. However, the exact opposite happens, and sovereigntist militants and their sympathisers declare open season on our community.  For the general populace the incidents of intolerance begin, many not seen for a generation:
http://oqla.org/en/discussion/media/119-child-assaulted-for-speaking-english-in-public  (a teenager is assaulted for speaking English outside his house while walking with friends)

English speakers in QC begin to feel the intolerance everywhere, even assaults in the Metro:
http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/10/31/montreal-stm-assault-savane-witness.html  (earlier in the year there was refusal to service English speakers, and this woman, Mina Barack was assaulted for simply wanting to be served in English)

Assaults in Hospital cafeteria lineups for speaking English (allergic reaction from tomatoes):
http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/tom-kott/anglophone-quebec_b_2053199.html

Or even worse, when calling for heath services, while their daughter is in convulsions, Mr Bergeron is passed through a language test before provided service:
http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/family-furious-over-...

Then, Minister Diane de Courcy, launches a proposal for yet another segregationist law, Bill 14. What is Bill 14?
http://www.thesuburban.com/article.php?id=1072&...

Hearings begin Sprin 2013, as you can see above, and in the main pitch you can hear my plea before Parlment do stop attacking our community and instead, have a comission to examine existing discrminatory legislation.

Despite all the hearings, the Human Rights Commission and the Quebec Bar Association denouncing the law, it passed into second reading (almost law), even after 40 thousand signatures ALSO are acquired in a petition against the law!
http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2013/05/21/quebec-bill-14-petition-national-assembly-geoff-kelley.html
And the Members of Parliament for the CAQ party (recycled separatists) let the law pass into second reading, despite their demands for revisions, which never happen: http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/20...

Here is the submission to Parliament in QC City February 09, 2013,
Revised April 04th, 2013, Updated After speech April 14th, 2013
TO: Louisette Cameron, Clerk, Ed. Pamphile-Le May, 1035,
rue des Parlementaires, QC, QC

RE: Presentation by the Quebec Office of the English Language:
Consultation on Bill 14 (Act to amend Bill 101) by the Committee on Culture and Education

Madame la Présidente Lorraine Richard,
Madame la Ministre Diane de Courcy,
Honourable Members of the Committee,

Thank you for having us. I just wanted to say that it would be nice if this was also in Montreal, [and that we] have some of the hearings in Montreal, since approximately %80 of the English speaking community in Quebec is based around Montreal.[i]

I am the volunteer Spokesperson for the non-profit organisation Quebec Office of the English Language (l’Office québécois de la langue anglaise - OQLA.org nous avons autour de 6 milles membres). It is time for our organisations, several organisations, and sister groups (CRITIQ – Canadian Rights in QC [speaking tomorrow], Unity Group here with me right now, PutBackTheFlag.com – thankfully its [Canadian flag] is still there), and MNAs (thanks to the [QC] Liberals here for saying a clear NO to Bill 14 already) begin to voice their support for the ‘other’ Official Language in Quebec, English. Why? Since most, the majority of Quebeckers want to move on from the separatist agenda and re-enforce their ties with the rest of Canada: a good start would be embracing the English language.

Firstly, and most importantly, we believe that the, English be returned to a fully Official Language status in QC to respect the constitution and our shared history. We strongly believe that the trend, as set out in the proposed Bill 14, needs reversal in order to give the 80 plus English Speaking communities across Quebec respite from the constant and methodological reduction of services.

It takes an ignorant person refer to English as a ‘Foreign’ language in Quebec. Furthermore, refusing Institutionalised Bilingualism is the same as prevention of advancement of our community, and is a key factor of the tyrannical Linguicisim in Quebec. Et je parle de quelqu’un qui est bilingue, de Vancouver, et je suis outré de ce qui se passe au Québec !

Bill 14 wishes to legislate ‘identity’, yet another unwanted ‘clause’ that would hang over on our community, and further reason to legitimise discrimination based on language. Predominance we had before [Bill 22], Bill 101 said we were non-official speakers in our own province, now you want to legitimise [legislate] ‘identity’!?), hitherto additional reasoning to make non-francophones feel that they are second class in their home and native province. Furthermore, playing identity politics is irresponsible, and I do not believe you are sincerely responsible Madame le Ministre [Diane de Courcy], but it is par for the course with ethno-nationalists here in Quebec, who think they have replaced the First Nations, who primarily use English (Mohawks, Cree, Hurons, [Innu]…), who speak amongst each other, who live double [the] discrimination. This is why Aboriginals have been very offended with the linguistic segregation proposed by this PQ Bill, these policies and rhetoric, this has been going on since last summer.  Legislating the QC Identity as FR-only, over-writing the true history of Quebec in Canada, would be a violation of the Human Rights Charter in itself: Section 10, language as a prohibited grounds of discrimination, which leads me to my next point.

It would seem there is little respect for the Universality of Human Rights in this province, since again, Bill 14 wishes to amend our Quebec Human Rights Charter, to simply do away with Ethnic Communities (ce n’est pas simplement une question de semantiques) and turn them into indefensible, e.g. from the standpoint of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Hague, changing them to ‘cultural communities’ would have this effect. Il semble que les consequences de cette loi ne sont pas reconnues. Several Barristers (including Colin Standish, here from Université Laval, Brent Tyler was here before) have come forward to contribute to the Montreal Gazette denouncing this attempt, yet another, to legislate away the rights of minorities.

If anything should be done regarding related legislation (Bill 101, 22, 178…whatever, the list goes on), it is time to consider these four simple concessions to the non-Francophone community that make up around 20% of the population and pay approximately 40% of taxes - believe it or not. It was René-Lévesque who said to us; he’s standing [right] out there [of the assembly], his statue standing right out there, that if you pay taxes, you are Quebecker. We certainly do not feel that way, and Bill 14 will continue to make us feel as ‘foreigners’ in our own province, since it is against the other Official Language of our country, Canada! Quebec is not a country. Le but, il semble, est de se débarrasser des Anglophones avec ce projet de loi, et les droits de la majorité en même temps. Le droit de la majorité d’apprendre l’anglais comme il faut, pour réussir en affaires, pour réussir avec le monde [en] entier.

There is a great opportunity to bring balance back and respect of the Rule of Law in QC. Now that the Charbonneau commission has made a clean sweep of corruption, we need a similar commission to examine existing discriminatory legislation. As such, a ‘stronger Bill 101’ is completely and totally inappropriate.  As the Suburban’s Editor, Beryl Wajsman, has stated – Bill 14: Don’t Even Think About It! Instead, Bill 101 should be replaced with Bill 199, as submitted by Neill Cameron, in the early nineties.

If Britain and France had an Entente Cordiale, il y a un siècle a hundred years ago England and France had an Entente Cordiale, why not here in Quebec? We are all neighbours, we live next to each other – mon ami Bertrand en face de moi, et mes autres amis francophones [ils se rendre compte que] we do not need a logistic [logical] division anymore! [There is no physical Manche between us, I was supposed to say] This Legal divide has been placed between us by opportunistic politicians, inebriated nationalists, separatist militants (caribous), et al.

Secondly, we need increased access to our bilingual English public schools (starting with the EMSB and LBPSB immediately, who have been short of ‘oxygen’ for years) – some 10,000 non-eligible children per year.  Immigrants, especially those from English-speaking jurisdictions outside of Canada, should have the full freedom of choice in public schools to respect U.N. Conventions that existing provincial legislation currently flouts, and would only worsen with Bill 14 regarding CEGEP access, and openly disrespect Military Families. We would accept, as a proper management decision made by the Quebec Government that has its ENTIRE population’s interests considered, at an absolute minimum that a proportional percentage of immigrants (approx. 20%) are allowed into the English School System. A system, I might add, which produces a qualified majority of bilingual Quebeckers, as Angela Mancini recently made clear, thus indirectly contributing to linguistic majority.

The third community need is guaranteed bilingual medical services. Considering the Federal Government provides the QC Provincial treasury with special allocations for our community, why is this currently an issue? Given the systemic corruption identified by the Charbonneau Commission and ‘le nivellement vers le bas’, one can only speculate why we think that our Heath services are not negotiable. Nobody should have to pass a language test to ‘qualify’ for medical services! Mark S. Bergeron’s incident with an Ambulance technician during Autumn past was horrifying - he has since stepped forward to denounce the situation we are in, and is current Leader of the Equality Party 2.0! It should be noted that in Ontario, the French Language Services Act recently celebrated 25 years of existence. Why does our minority in QC, almost double the size, not have the equivalent agreement? Why do francophones from outside of Quebec, namely Sentators Maria Chaput and Andrée Champagne, in their report from 2010, recommend that monies go directly to our institutions?

Our fourth demand, and last request, is to dismiss any threshold to have bilingual municipalities revoked. Alternatively, leave it entirely in the hands of the municipality, without OQLF harassment and respect for localised democracy.  This would stop this PQ-imposed threshold that is unrealistic for the survival of our communities, despite peaceful EN & FR speaking neighbourhoods thriving as part of the inter-woven multi-cultural (and not unicultural, unilingual) fabric over hundreds of years - even after two conquests (Kirke, Wolfe) and two lost referendums.  There are countless examples of street, parks and monuments are renamed without public involvement and are repetitive attempts to outlaw the use of English by any means possible. En sommaire, il faut la préservation de la richesse de notre province, quoi que ce soit, au niveau de côté linguistique, de l’histoire.  Au Québec cela ne se passe pas uniquement et seulement en français !

In expectation of good faith, this will involve changes to Bill 101 as opposed to Bill 14, although we suggest the former be replaced with former MNA for Jacques-Cartier, Neil Cameron’s Bill 199, Charter of the French and English Languages. It would resolve much of the linguistic tension by declaring both languages equal since French in our province is not threatened with well past 7M people speaking it.

Furthermore, this would respect the constitution of our great country by promoting the use of English also to save Quebec from this poor, bankrupt, and isolated province it has increasingly become over the past generation, and to remedy the colossal negative interdependence with the rest of Canada.

We hope to have the Liberal + CAQ MNAs agree to concede these four principles so that Minority Communities reassured publicly that their interests be recognised in eventual legislative change. Only, in this way, can the economy profit from being open to the Lingua Franca of the business world.

Yours sincerely, Veuillez accepter mes meilleures sentiments distinguées.

Hugo Shebbeare

hugo.shebbeare@facebook.com or Hugo@Shebbeare.com

I am a Champion for Canada, et le Québec est Inclus dans Mon Pays !

[i] Bill 14 would force all small businesses to work in French only, meaning that the heart of economic activity in Quebec would take yet another huge hit. Approximately 80% of jobs are held in small businesses, and thus, not only will Montreal continue its steady decline since the late seventies, and loss of financial centre of Canada to Toronto, but become a complete economic backwater.

Please, as Tony Kondaks states, Do Not Let Quebec Get Away With This
http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/tony-kondaks/quebec-language-laws-bill-14-french_b_1451014.html  (and by supporting this campaign we will put up a fight against legalised discrmination Quebec has not seen the likes of before)

Since June, I have joined the Equality Party 2.0 as Executive Vice President, since I believe that we need to mount effective political representation in QC City (our provincial parliament) to counter the hard-line Nationalists and Separatists.

story:
Send Me to the FrontLines


I have had a heart to fight sex slavery for some time now, and this past year, I was presented with a chance not to sit on the sidelines but to really do  something. I have joined with a nonprofit called The Exodus Road (a registered 501c3) that works with investigators in SE Asia and India. Working with local police, these investigative teams find and gather the evidence necessary for police to conduct rescues and raids. To date, The Exodus Road has supported the rescue of 253 victims of sex trafficking.

I have been on the ground for almost two months, working in dangerous boarder town brothels and bars. I have personally been involved in may survellence cases, sting operations and rescues. The work is often very hard mentally and emotionally as well as physically. I have had to put to use all my training from the military and law enforcement.  I am currently working with a team in SE Asia that already has solid police contacts and have been active in undercover investigations for several years. Currently the team is working on 40 active cases--including everything from pedophilia, minors sold for sex, restricted movement and trafficking across borders.

I do not recieve a salary. All I need is the funding to do the work. I'd be honored if you would consider joining me in going into the darkness for the sake of the child and the oppressed. 

What We Need & What You Get

Because I am working with a nonprofit that seeks to maximize donated funds for raids/rescues/investigative expenses, I am needing to raise my own funding to do this work for six months. I am asking my friends and family and community to pitch in and help me do this work. Here's what I need:

I live off of ten US dollars a day or 300 dollars a month. That goes towards food, lodging and other expneses. I have raised a large portion already, but I am still short. I am asking 100 friends if they would consider donating 20 dollars each.  

You can find out more about the organization by visiting the website here:www.theExodusRoad.com. They are a 501c3 in good standing with both the state and federal government, and all gifts are tax-deductible. 

The Impact

To date, The Exodus Road has utilized undercover investigators around the world to fuel the rescues of 253 victims of sex trafficking, all with local police partners in SE Asia and India. With more slaves today than at any other time in human history, they are strategically equipping an army of trained, skilled investigators to assist police conduct raids, rescues and arrests. 

The team I will be assisting is in dire need of help-- both in basic surveillance and in administrative support. They are currently working over 50 active cases of trafficking, underage prostitution, and pedophilia, and I will be trained to assist them in any investigative, surveillance or support capacity that they need.

In the course of the upcoming six months, it is estimated that I will assist with at least 40 cases of human trafficking and sexual slavery which will likely result in the rescue of 15-30 individuals. I will also likely help in the investigations of 50-75 places of interest and at least 4 cases involving the arrests of pedophiles.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate financially to launch me to the field, help us by spreading the word! SHARE online via the indiegogo's share tools. 

You can also connect with The Exodus Road on Facebook (@The Exodus Road)  to get current updates by liking our page or following us on Twitter (@theexodusroad). 

If you'd like text updates to your phone of real-time raids and operations, text "ER" to #51555. 

FrontLine Footage

Check out this video of the type of work I'll be doing: 

https://vimeo.com/72916137

Working with local police, these investigative teams find and gather the evidence necessary for police to conduct rescues and raids. To date, The Exodus Road has supported the rescue of 253 victims of sex trafficking.I have been on the ground for almost two months, working in dangerous boarder town brothels and bars. story:
Hello, and welcome to the page of 302 for Haiti!

We are a group composed of four college bound seniors and one adult. In an attempt to make a difference and have a truly memorable summer before college, we decided our efforts would be best spent planning a mission trip to Haiti.

The country of Haiti has been unfortunate enough to have spent the last few decades dealing with the cycles of poverty, political turmoil, and natural disaster. Though the country is staggeringly beautiful, both the urban and rural areas are thick with the sight of poverty. Crumbling buildings, ramshackle shelters, and tent cities make up a good deal of the residences that can be found. Accompanied by the lowest caloric intake per capita in the western hemisphere, no job base, and failing infrastructure, there is no doubt Haiti is in need of help.

With two of us having prior experience in country, there is no doubt in our minds that the people of Haiti could not be a more deserving people for the help that we hope to provide. Mission of Hope is our chosen host mission, they stood out the most to us, because of the quality work they do and our experience there.

The goal we put up is a basic figure that will help alleviate the personal cost of the mission. The major costs we face include airfare from PHI to Haiti, a week of room and board at the mission, and vaccination costs. Any amount of money we raise over what we need for the mission trip to take place at all will go directly to the mission in the form of requested supplies, of which 100% go directly to those most in need. 

The work we do during the week is evenly balanced between running a camp for Haitian children and work projects, two aspects vital to the long term recovery of Haiti.

Thank you all so much for your support. Check out the perks for all the ways in which we want an opportunity to thank you. Check us out or contact us at our Email or other networking sites!

Email: 302forhaiti@gmail.com

Facebook

Twitter

Youtube

story:
Joy for Children Uganda (JFCU) is a non-governmental organization that advocates for the rights of children in Uganda.

In Kampala, Uganda’s capital, JFCU implements the Slum Women Development Project. The project started in 2010 and is based on community outreach carried out in four slum areas in Kampala. One component of the project focuses on the empowerment of families with children with disabilities.

The picture shows Nakibuka Hajjara together with JFCU's social worker Annah Japendi. Nakibuka is 15 years old and suffers from Cerebral Palsy. She is not able to walk or stand; she has difficulties with coordination and stiff muscles; also she cannot speak. Nakibuka’s mother died when she was only one year old, she currently lives with her grandmother. Her father resents her for, he doesn’t want to be a father of a child with disabilities. She is only taken care of by her grandmother.

Nakibuka, together with her grandmother live in Bwaise, one of the slum areas in Kampala. Nakibuka’s grandmother tries to earn a living by roasting chicken at the roadside. The small house (consisting of one room) where Nakibuka lives with her grandmother is regularly flooded during rainy seasons. Nakibuka’s grandmother not only provides for Nakibuka, but also for seven more grandchildren without any support from either government or the community.

Since Nakibuka is not able to walk, she spends all her days sitting in a wooden chair, which her grandmother made for her. The chair doesn’t support Nakibuka’s arms, feet or back. Because of this, her condition has worsened; spinal and hip deformities have been reinforced. Additionally, Nakibuka suffers from sore pressures.

Nakibuka needs a special wheelchair for Cerebral Palsy, in order to avoid further worsening of her health. 

We are asking for 500 US-Dollars to buy a special wheelchair for Nakibuka. Any contribution towards this cause will be appreciated.

story:
The Right to Know Day – 28 September

The Access to Information Programme (AIP) has been working for 22 years for free access to government held information in Bulgaria and the Right to Know Day is the climax in the national campaign for encouraging the exercise of the right to information and pushing for enhanced government transparency and accountability.

The Right to Know Day was established in 2002 at an international conference in Sofia, Bulgaria and since then celebrated by thousands of Freedom of Information Advocates around the globe.

Due to its impact, 28 September was recently recognized by the UNESCO as the International Day for the Universal Access to Information.

Being one of the founders of the Right to Know Day, for 16 years the AIP holds the Awards Ceremony in Bulgaria.

The Right to Know Day Awards Ceremony in Bulgaria

At the Right to Know Day Awards Ceremony held on Sept. 28, the AIP gives the “Golden Key” awards to citizens, journalists, and NGOs, who have actively exercised their right of access to information and public bodies with excellent transparency practices. Institutions with bad transparency practices receive the “Padlock” and the “Tied Key” anti-awards.

The event has gained very high legitimacy. The Golden Key award has become a symbol of freedom of information, transparency and accountability.  The annual media outreach is of dozens publications, radio and TV shows, spreading the news on unique access to information success stories.

The Right to Know Day has thus turned as the strongest tool in the AIP campaign for encouraging the exercise of the right to information and pushing for enhanced government transparency and accountability.

Why is Free Access to Government Information and the Right to Know so important:

  • It is a human right!
  • Provides for Government transparency by casting light on its work;
  • Is necessary for informed public participation in decision and policy making;
  • Helps exercise control over Government and keep them open and accountable;
  • Empowers citizens to exercise other rights – like freedom of expression, the right to education, the right to health, the right to clean environment, etc.

The Right to Know in Bulgaria

In Bulgaria, the active, consistent and persistent exercise of the right to information, and the support provided by the AIP resulted in:

  • Proactive publication of information essential for effective public participation in decision and policy making of public bodies;
  • Disclosure of documents related to public funds expenditure, city planning and roads infrastructure; the health and safety of citizens; environmental protection; activities of public law organizations like hospitals, universities, and schools;
  • Free online access to the Trade Companies Register, the State Gazette; the Registers of Assets of High Ranking Officials; Public Procurements; Conflict of Interests Declarations; and decades of others;
  • Online access to government contracts and related documents.

Help the Access to Information Programme reach the goal of $ 5,000 to organize and hold the 16th Right to Know Day Awards Ceremony in Bulgaria on September 28.

Everyone can contribute with a minimum of $5 or higher. Every contribution matters!

We need your support to:

  • Run the Right to Know Day nominations campaign – dozens of nominations are collected in six categories, each being a unique story how the right to information is exercised in public good. All cases are available at: http://www.righttoknowday.net/nominations/2018/.
  • Make the Golden Key, Padlock, and Tied Key Awards - the Golden Key  has become a legitimate symbol of freedom of information, creating a competition for its win.
  • Organize and hold the 16th Right to Know Day Awards Ceremony – the event is a celebration of dozens of advocates for freedom of information, exchange of ideas, outline strategies.
  • Run the media and public campaign – the nominations, the Awards Ceremony on 28 Sept, the awardees are accompanied by intensive public campaign and attract immense media coverage providing for the visibility and impact of the Right to Know Day Campaign in Bulgaria.

The Access to Information Programme Foundation

The Access to Information Programme is a Bulgarian nonprofit organization established in 1996. Our mission is to assist the exercise of the right to information. We are doing it by:

  • Monitoring and advocating for better Access to Information legislation;
  • Monitoring access to information practices;
  • Performing special surveys on access to information implementation practices and government transparency;
  • Maintaining a network of journalists in 27 regions in Bulgaria;
  • Preparing annual reports on the state of access to information;
  • Providing legal aid and representation in court on access to information cases;
  • Running campaigns to raise awareness on the right to information;
  • Holding FOI trainings for civil servants, journalists, and nongovernmental organizations;
  • Holding the Right to Know Day Awards Ceremony in Bulgaria on September 28;
  • Active participation in national and international networks advocating for freedom of information.

In its 22 years of work, the AIP has cooperated and contributed to freedom of information campaigns in a number of countries in Europe, Africa, South and North America, Asia.

My name is Allen Smith. I grew up in Colorado and now living in California. Helping the Homeless USA is a new foundation being formed by three Americans from Pennsylvania, Colorado and California. We want to help the homeless right here in the USA. Although this concept is not new, we feel our concept is. There is no excuse to have homeless here in the wealthiest country in the world. We started the foundation because of seeing so many homeless still struggling to survive in our country. By being involved in the formation of this foundation, you will be participating in a cause that is bigger than yourself. We want to help the homeless by helping them get jobs, find a place to live and get back on their feet. We want to change their situation, not just help them stay in their situation. Your contribution will help us with the legal fees in setting up the foundation, office space, transportation costs, events, staffing and storage of goods. We will be a different foundation in that we will be the first on the scene to natural disasters as well. There are 32,000 new homeless people as a result of the Colorado fires. We want to be there to help. We will reward all our contributors with an "I helped start the helpingthehomelessusa.org foundation" T-shirt that you can proudly wear in your community. The contributors that donate $1,000 or more will receive the platinum recognition T-shirt, their name on our brochures, a picture on our website and a Best Buy gift card. We appreciate all of you that are helping to start our foundation. You will impact your community by helping the homeless to get back on their feet, be able to have employment, sustain a roof over their head and increase the value of your community. Imagine a United States where everyone has a place to live, eat and sleep. If you don't have money right now to give, that's ok, but you can still help. How can you help? You can get the word out by placing this URL, http://www.indiegogo.com/helpingthehomelessusa?a=789951 on your social network site such as Facebook, Myspace or Blog. Let's help give to the homeless and not just during the holiday season. Your "helpingthehomelessusa.org" team appreciates and thanks you in advance for your contribution.

story:
Wesley (“Wes”) Johnson, a family man and former Marine who was recently arrested because of antiquated laws regarding alleged growth and distribution of marijuana, is kindly asking for financial assistance from friends, family, and the general public to help him win his fight against the inherently unfair and overzealous charges brought against him by the Sandy Springs Police Department.
Who Wes is:
Wes was born in Tennessee and, after graduating from high school, joined the United States Marine Corp because of his belief that we must ensure the rights and freedoms that our forefathers fought and died for. From 1995-1998, Mr. Johnson’s superior skills, persistence, and attitude led him to be a weapons instructor (specifically, pistol training) at the United States Marine Corps Base in Quantico, Virginia, during which time he instructed approximately 3000 marines in how to protect themselves, their fellow soldiers, and their country.
In 1998, following his service as an instructor at Quantico, Mr. Johnson moved to Atlanta where he soon met the love of his life, Melissa. In 2004, Wes and Melissa were blessed with a beautiful daughter. In 2006, Wes and Melissa were blessed with a son. Both of their children have proven excellent students and have remained at the top of their respective classes since kindergarten. To this day, Wes and Melissa remain happy and devoted parents to their children, and the possibility of Wes losing time from his children’s lives is the major factor leading to this fundraising campaign.
During his time in the Marines, Wes began experiencing a severe cough later diagnosed as tuberculosis and several other medical issues that would not ultimately be diagnosed for years to come, including a congenital defect of a rotated right hip which contributed to and exacerbated several back ailments he now experiences and genetic fatty cysts which have invaded his body. In years that have followed, Wes has been diagnosed with arthritis, gout and a blot clot that ran the entire length of his right leg that nearly left him dead from two pulmonary embolisms. To this day, he has a filter near his heart designed to catch clots and suffers from excessive fatigue. Wes was, and still is, in constant, severe pain, and has difficulty sleeping, walking, and moving in general, and was instructed by his physician to quit his chosen profession as a chef. These symptoms often prevent Wes from working (as a car salesman, chef, and an organic gardener, providing local restaurants and farmer’s markets with herbicide-free and pesticide-free watermelon, tomatoes, squash, okra, peppers, blueberries, cucumbers and lettuces) and enjoying his hobbies (walking, cooking, gardening and ice skating with his children).
Mr. Johnson has been an ardent supporter of medical marijuana legalization since 2000. Mr. Johnson co-founded rescheduleme.org, and industrialhemp4vicotry.org, two organizations dedicated to having cannabis rescheduled from the Schedule 1 category. The Schedule 1 category is for drugs with a high potential for abuse, that have no currently accepted medical use in the United States, and for which there is a lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision. In addition to being a supporter of medical marijuana, Mr. Johnson is a regular supporter and advocate of St. Jude’s Children’s Hospital, The Salvation Army, The Girl Scouts of America, Goodwill, the Foundation for Free Flight and the Wounded Warrior Fund.
Legal Defense:
On June 2, 2015, officers from the Sandy Springs Police Department entered Mr. Johnson’s residence and allegedly found marijuana. Perhaps it’s a strange coincidence he became a target shortly after he ramped up his advocacy efforts, perhaps not. After allegedly finding marijuana, he was charged with manufacturing and possession of marijuana with intent to distribute, trafficking of marijuana, and firearm possession during the commission of a felony.
Mr. Johnson is a patriotic American who loves his family, his community, and his country. Mr. Johnson has become the poster child for what is wrong with America’s failed “War on Drugs.” With Colorado, Washington, Alaska, Oregon, and even Washington D.C. fully legalizing marijuana, and 19 other states (including Georgia!) with some form of medical marijuana legalized, the prosecution and possible imprisonment of Mr. Johnson reflect the inherent unfairness of the charges brought against him. His children run the risk of losing their father during their formative years, and witnessing their mother, whose health is deteriorating due to Lupus, struggle to provide for them.
It will cost Mr. Johnson ten thousand dollars just to get through the pre-trial phase of his legal battle. Mr. Johnson is requesting financial help from his friends, family and anyone else who feels he is being wrongfully prosecuted to assist him in paying his legal bills. All of the money raised from this campaign will go directly to his legal defense bills. Please help Wes fight for his freedom and his family.

story: Our church houses guests once a week during the winter months from the local homeless community. We have the opportunity to add a washer and dryer to our shelter for a discounted price of $500. We are a small congregation with few resources. Your help will make it possible for guests to clean their clothes and for volunteers to more easily clean sheets, blankets, and towels. Though this seems a small way to help, you will receive the satisfaction in knowing that what seems a small deed will multiply and help countless persons in need.

story:
Who are we?

The long and illustrious history of the Second Battalion, Fourth Marines began in April of 1914 during WWI when it was activated as one of the three battalions of the Fourth Marine Regiment.  The Marine infantry battalion earned the nickname, “The Magnificent Bastards” during Vietnam.

In February 2004, “The Magnificent Bastards” deployed to Ramadi, Iraq, the provincial capital of the Al Anbar Province, in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Battle of Ramadi was pivotal for coalition operations in the Al-Anbar province. 2/4, along with the 1st BDE, 1st ID engaged insurgent forces in Ramadi in early April 2004.

The battle began at midmorning when Marine patrols fanned out across Ramadi to provide security and search for roadside bombs. Three squads from Third Platoon, Golf Company, 2nd Battalion 4th Marines set off on separate routes. They worked their way west from a Combat Outpost to the government center, 2 miles away, where they would link-up and stand guard.

During this movement a squad was ambushed and the adjacent squads came under fire while attempting to rescue the ambushed squad. Insurgents armed with small-arms and RPGs continued to battle the Marines for nearly 2-hours before the Marines could be effectively reinforced. It was one of the deadliest days of the war, but the Magnificent Bastards showed the insurgents that they were a far superior fighting unit.

Marines and Army soldiers killed an estimated 250 rebels from April 6 to April 10 in fighting that shattered the insurgent offensive. 13 Marines were killed and 25 were wounded in the battle on April 6. Another 4 were killed over the next four days. The battalion conducted support and stability operations (SASO) within the city and served with distinction while engaging insurgent forces in Iraq. 2/4 returned to Camp Pendleton in September 2004.

(information from the oficial website of 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines.) 

 

What We Need & What You Get:

Help us honor our fallen brothers from the April, 2004 firefight.  We are hosting a memorial reunion weekend 23-28 May, 2013 in Bemidji, MN.  The money we raise will be used to provide meals for the Veterans and their families as well as provide funds for the Veterans who would not otherwise be able to come out to pay their respects--they come from all over the country.  No perks this year other than feeling a personal satisfaction for supporting the troops and a good deed done.  But we will send to everyone who donates a group photo of the Marines at the reunion to express our thanks.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some people just can’t contribute and we understand that, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please pray for us, specifically the families of our fallen brothers
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Thank you and Semper Fidelis.

~The Magnificent Bastards
story_txt:
Who are we?
The long and illustrious history of the Second Battalion, Fourth Marines began in April of 1914 during WWI when it was activated as one of the three battalions of the Fourth Marine Regiment.  The Marine infantry battalion earned the nickname, “The Magnificent Bastards” during Vietnam.
In February 2004, “The Magnificent Bastards” deployed to Ramadi, Iraq, the provincial capital of the Al Anbar Province, in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Battle of Ramadi was pivotal for coalition operations in the Al-Anbar province. 2/4, along with the 1st BDE, 1st ID engaged insurgent forces in Ramadi in early April 2004.
The battle began at midmorning when Marine patrols fanned out across Ramadi to provide security and search for roadside bombs. Three squads from Third Platoon, Golf Company, 2nd Battalion 4th Marines set off on separate routes. They worked their way west from a Combat Outpost to the government center, 2 miles away, where they would link-up and stand guard.
During this movement a squad was ambushed and the adjacent squads came under fire while attempting to rescue the ambushed squad. Insurgents armed with small-arms and RPGs continued to battle the Marines for nearly 2-hours before the Marines could be effectively reinforced. It was one of the deadliest days of the war, but the Magnificent Bastards showed the insurgents that they were a far superior fighting unit.
Marines and Army soldiers killed an estimated 250 rebels from April 6 to April 10 in fighting that shattered the insurgent offensive. 13 Marines were killed and 25 were wounded in the battle on April 6. Another 4 were killed over the next four days. The battalion conducted support and stability operations (SASO) within the city and served with distinction while engaging insurgent forces in Iraq. 2/4 returned to Camp Pendleton in September 2004.
(information from the oficial website of 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines.) 
 
What We Need & What You Get:
Help us honor our fallen brothers from the April, 2004 firefight.  We are hosting a memorial reunion weekend 23-28 May, 2013 in Bemidji, MN.  The money we raise will be used to provide meals for the Veterans and their families as well as provide funds for the Veterans who would not otherwise be able to come out to pay their respects--they come from all over the country.  No perks this year other than feeling a personal satisfaction for supporting the troops and a good deed done.  But we will send to everyone who donates a group photo of the Marines at the reunion to express our thanks.
 
Other Ways You Can Help:
Some people just can’t contribute and we understand that, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please pray for us, specifically the families of our fallen brothers
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Thank you and Semper Fidelis.
~The Magnificent Bastards

story:
WHY TUCKER NEEDS YOUR HELP . . .

In recent weeks, University of Southern California student Tucker Reed has received substantial media attention for her self-advocacy in the wake of her rape by a fellow USC student.  For months Tucker chronicled her experience online, crafting a resource for other victims, writing openly about the overwhelming prejudice faced by victims who seek justice for their assaults -- prejudice perpetuated in Tucker's case by both local police as well as school administrators who sought to dismiss the validity of four recorded confessions in which Tucker's rapist admits to raping her and an email in which he admits he was aware the two had sex Tucker didn't want.

From Tucker's blog:
"Maybe I shouldn’t be writing this.  Maybe admitting that I am scared and hurt will discourage other women from speaking up.  And that is the worst thing of all.  Because it makes it harder for the women who do speak, knowing they are few and far between.  And it makes it easier for the rapists who decide to rape, knowing so few women will dare speak about it. But I needed to own up to it.  I needed to admit how scared and helpless I feel."

As a consequence of her openness regarding her assault, Tucker's rapist is suing her for "intentional infliction of emotional distress" and defamation.

We have set our fundraising goal at Indiegogo's minimum of $500.00.  To give you some perspective, the average attorney charges about $300.00 per hour. Any financial support to defray the substantial cost of legal protection will help at this point, but we actively encourage you to donate to this campaign even if we reach our stated goal.

Tucker is working with the Student Coalition Against Rape (SCAR) at USC to establish a permanent fund for the defense of any and all students who face legal fees as a consequence of self-advocacy.  This fund will directly support not just Tucker's defense, but all future USC students who face similarly terrible circumstances.

No one who is victimized and then forced to shoulder the burden of pursuing recourse should also face the additional burden of affording mounting legal fees, and student victims should not be expected to assume the responsibility of legal bills on top of the cost of school tuition and college loans.

It is SCAR's hope that through this campaign, we can establish a precedent of providing financial aid to students -- male and female -- who pursue justice for sexual violence suffered while working toward earning their degrees.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN SUPPORT TUCKER AND SCAR . . .

Any amount of donation will help, but if you would like to contribute to the cause and cannot do so financially, please consider writing a letter to the University of Southern California administration requesting that they improve their policies protecting student victims of interpersonal violence.

Form letters are available on SCAR's official website.

story:
Imagine losing everything.

Every woman I work with at the Karen Women’s Organization on the Thailand/Burma border was forced to abandon her home at gunpoint, flee into the jungle with their family and forage for food, just hoping to stay alive. 

It is difficult to understand the suffering of others until you have walked a mile in their shoes. And although I will never fully understand the struggles and sacrifices the women at KWO have had to face, the more time I spend working with this group of exceptional woman, I get a deeper glimpse into lives of women and girls from Burma who have suffered great injustices.

I have been working with women in refugee camps near the Thai/Burmese border for a year. I want to continue to work side by side with them and I need your help to do it. 

KWO came into existence as women worked together to fill the gaps in services in the refugee camps and to increase the role of women in the community.  They advocate for women’s rights, conduct leadership development trainings, educate women on a broad range of issues such as women’s rights under the UN Charter, and educate the refugee camp communities about their rights of return to their villages. 

(If you want to learn more about KWO, visit their website at: karenwomen.org.)

Women are the leaders in these refugee communities, yet when it comes to planning for refugee return and peace talks in Burma, women have for the most part been excluded. Women’s needs are not going to be met if there are no women at the table! That’s why KWO’s leadership development and advocacy is so critical. 

Click here to read a letter of recommendation written by KWO's General Secretary, Naw K'nyaw Paw, acknowledging my work with KWO and their desire to have me continue with their organization. 

I am writing to ask you to help me raise $10,000 to allow me to continue to work with (KWO). I have already secured $3,000 from donations from my previous campaign. In addition, I have been offered a challenge grant, this means, I will receive a 100% match for every dollar I raise from my friends and family, so anything you can contribute is doubled in value!

How the donations will be spent:

-  A plane ticket costs approximately $2,000 so every mile of the 9,000 journey to Thailand costs around a quarter. To sponsor 100 miles please consider donating $25 or 1,000 miles for $250

- Cell phone bill for one month to communicate with regional offices and refugee camps 

- $20 per month or $240 for the year

-  Rent – $150 per month or $1,800 for the year

- Food to fuel work - $200 per month or $2,400 for the year

Being able to stay in Thailand, continue this work, and support these amazing women means so much to me. I would be so grateful for your support right now.

KWO's 28th anniversary of KWO Day. KWO was formed in 1949 and reestablished in 1985.

International Elimination of Violence Against Women Day celebrated in Karen State, Burma. KWO staff worked to raise awareness for the elimination of violence against women to the Karen community.

story:
It's Working!

Thanks to our supporters, we hired our very first part-time staff. We have more brilliant and dedicated women volunteering than ever before. We got our first small grant from Spirit Mountain Community Fund, with more potential grants in the works. We created and implemented self-defense pilot program for high school students. We've created training opportunities for women from coast to coast. Best of all, in 2017 we provided over 100 empowerment-based women's and youth defense trainings in 13 cities. Only halfway through 2018, we have already provided 102 trainings in 10 cities. We're on track to double our offerings over the course of only one year, and so much of this is thanks to supporters like you.

A majority of our capacity is due to contributions from individual supporters. Thank you does not begin to cover it. Without organizations like this one, access to self-defense training would be restricted to women who can afford to pay $100+ a month on average to a gym - often for impractical, male-dominated training that doesn't include verbal skills or a focus on women. Together, we're raising the bar, and working to make accessible, reality-based, quality training the norm.

The demand is there. The dedication and skill from our staff and volunteers is there too. But if we want to keep growing and serving more women, we need your help. Your contribution toward our funding goal not only sustains our existing programs that are going strong, but helps us reach out and create training opportunities in new venues and communities. In particular, we need to make sure that our training is reaching vulnerable and marginalized communities who need it most.

These Trainings Change Lives.

Our all-volunteer staff have provided thousands of women with free self-defense training, while helping women across the country bring empowerment-based self-defense to their communities. Our vision is unique. Unlike most self-defense programs, our services:

  • Always prioritize FREE training to women in need
  • Provide training in verbal boundary-setting and de-escalation skills - not just physical skills
  • Prioritize serving survivors of trauma
  • Address issues that women actually face, including verbal coercion, harassment, and emotional abuse
  • Empower women to bring self-defense training to other women in their own communities

Supporters like you have made it possible for us to expand across the United States from our flagship chapter. As of this year, we also have ongoing training available in Tulsa and NYC. We regularly have anywhere from 50-300 women attempting to sign up for each training we schedule. The demand is huge, and we need your help to meet it!

Donate to support us during this crucial time of growth, and let us send you a gift as thanks. The perks for donating to this campaign are unique designs created by volunteers. Your support goes directly to providing self-defense training to women, and to making sure we can continue to live up to our mission.

The Hard Parts.

This is the most ambitious fundraising goal we've ever set, and it's because our program goals are more ambitious than ever before. It costs anywhere from $150-$500 to put on a training, depending on factors like space rental, travel costs, accommodations for participants, and more. Since the vast majority of our trainings are free, our supporters are absolutely necessary to making this work. More than just being able to put on trainings, we need to make sure that our trainings are accessible and relevant to women beyond just those with means and privileges. Your support helps us ensure that we provide needed services to rural women, teens and youth, those with physical limitations, survivors of trauma, women experiencing poverty, and more. This training changes lives, and our team is confident that we can meet these challenges with your help.

Other Ways to Support.

Can't contribute right now? Doesn't mean you can't get involved! Here are some ways to help.

  • Share this page on your social media! Let your followers know why accessibility is important to you.
  • Click here to sign up for our email newsletter, and help us spread the word about trainings in your area.
  • Follow us on Facebook and Instagram!
  • Have you been to one of our trainings? Click here to tell us what you think! Testimonials help us improve our training and let others know about the benefits of empowerment-based self-defense.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Melissa Raguse, and I am the Executive Director and Founder of 1ForceUnited. I started this non-profit with 4 things in mind: Prevention, Protection, Accommodation, and Prosecution, all with goals to help end human trafficking. 
  • Our Mission: The 1ForceUnited Campaign exist to END Human Trafficking by Uniting with YOU to bring Freedom to the 27 million slaves in the world. We are a non profit organization based out of Fargo, ND that works with local community and out of state resources along with multiple partners that help supply our organization with the tools to rescue and restore victims. 
  • With the help from resources, partners, and YOU we can provide these victims with the protection and accommodation they need to heal and transition them back to a normal life.  

                                     

    

What We Need & What You Get

  • In order to provide the restoration process to the rescued victims, we need your help in Raising $25,000. This will provide the rescued victims with a restoration facility and crisis shelters within the state so that they have a place to heal. 
  • When you donate, You are helping us Restore the voices of those who didn't have one. Life is a gift and it should NEVER be for sale. With your donation you will receive some of our organizations perks, but most importantly you are receiving the knowing sense you helped save a life that will be restored and reunited with family. 
  • If we don't meet our goal, the funds will still go into the building of the facilities, so that we can have our doors open to the victims as soon as possible.

              


The Impact

  • Our organization will not be just in North Dakota. We are currently in the expansion process of moving into 3 other states. We hope to be in every state so that we can help rescue and restore as many victims as possible. Every state in the United States is affected by human trafficking and over 161 countries are involved in the exploitation of individuals for sex, labor, and organ harvesting. Your awareness and help are taking a stand to say No to Trafficking across the Globe. 


    Risks & Challenges

    • After graduating with a Criminal Justice Degree, working in the Criminal Justice field, and studying many cases that dealt with human trafficking, I came to realize that majority of the victims don't have a place to go after we bring them in. Once information is collected, more then 90% of them wind back up in the trafficking industry, whether as a sex slave or in the labor field. We need a shelter/facility to take them to so they can not only receive help and heal, but also help law enforcement catch the pimps/traffickers selling them. This will help prevent future victims in return.  
    • By having these facilities available, the police now have a place to take them to and work with them through cases in order to arrest the people who did this to them. The facilities also allow us to reunite them with family, prevent them from winding back up in the trafficking industry, and restore them so that they can return to a normal life. 
    • We have multiple resource partners in state and out that have already partnered with us to provide accommodations for the victims when our doors open, such as: health care, scholarships for college, food, clothing, counselling, animal therapy, job training, empowerment training, and much more. We are ready to help, we just need a facility for them now. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • WE are asking YOU to help us Spread the Awareness by Joining the Force. There are many ways to Get Involved: be a prayer warrior, share our organization with family and friends, share this campaign,  volunteer, intern, become a team leader or team member, be an advocate if you live out of state, work with us as a community, an out of state resource, or partner, become a monthly or one time donor, and follow us on FB, Twitter, and Instagram for the latest news/updates.

story:
Γιατί τρέχω στον 33Ο Μαραθώνιο Αθηνών

Τρέχω μαζί με την ομάδα του ελληνικού τμήματος της Διεθνούς Αμνηστίας, στα 42 χλμ και στηρίζω την εκστρατεία της οργάνωσης  υπέρ των δικαιωμάτων των προσφύγων. Τρέχω γιατί θέλω να υποστηρίξω με τον τρόπο αυτό την έρευνα και την εκστρατεία  της ΔΑ για τους πρόσφυγες και παράλληλα με τις προσπάθειες των άλλων οργανώσεων, κινημάτων, απλών πολιτών,  ο καθένας με τον τρόπο του και όλοι μαζί, να προστατευτούν οι ζωές και τα δικαιώματα των προσφύγων και να αναδειχθεί η ομορφιά της αλληλεγγύης.   

Γιατί είναι σημαντικό για εμένα να μαζέψω χρήματα 

Θέλω να γίνω ακόμη ένας που στηρίζει το έργο της Διεθνούς Αμνηστίας στην Ελλάδα. Στηρίζοντας την προσπάθειά μου  στηρίζεις μια ισχυρή παρουσία της Διεθνούς Αμνηστίας στην Ελλάδα που σημαίνει μεγαλύτερη πίεση στις ελληνικές και ευρωπαϊκές αρχές να σεβαστούν τα δικαιώματα των προσφύγων. Σημαίνει στήριξη των αλληλέγγυων και ακτιβιστών/ριών που δουλεύουν καθημερινά στην πρώτη γραμμή. Σημαίνει ανεξάρτητη και αξιόπιστη έρευνα που μεταφράζεται σε εκστρατείες ώστε η Ευρωπαϊκή Ένωση να καλωσορίζει τους πρόσφυγες και να σεβαστεί τα δικαιώματά τους.

Που θα πάνε τα χρήματα;

Τα χρήματα θα πάνε για τη δράση του ελληνικού τμήματος της Διεθνούς Αμνηστίας

και ειδικότερα για τη στήριξη της εκστρατείας SOSEurope που κινητοποιεί χιλιάδες ακτιβιστές και ακτιβίστριες στην Ευρώπη και τον κόσμο απαιτώντας το σεβασμό των δικαιωμάτων των προσφύγων. Οι εκστρατείες της Διεθνούς Αμνηστίας χρηματοδοτούνται αποκλειστικά από τις δωρεές των μελών και των υποστηρικτών της.

Οι θέσεις της Διεθνούς Αμνηστίας για την ΕΕ και τους πρόσφυγες

Οι Ευρωπαίοι ηγέτες πρέπει άμεσα:

·  Να αυξήσουν σημαντικά την υποστήριξή τους προς τα κράτη-μέλη της ΕΕ που είναι στην πρώτη γραμμή, έτσι ώστε να παρέχουν ανθρώπινες συνθήκες υποδοχής και να επισπεύσουν τη διαδικασία αιτημάτων ασύλου.

·  Να εξασφαλίσουν την πρόσβαση στο έδαφος της ΕΕ για πρόσφυγες που καταφτάνουν από τα εξωτερικά χερσαία σύνορα.

·  Να ανακουφίσουν την άμεση πίεση στα εξωτερικά σύνορα των χωρών με τη δημιουργία ενός συστήματος επείγουσας μετεγκατάστασης

·  Να αναθεωρήσουν την ευρωπαϊκή νομοθεσία η οποία περιορίζει την ελευθερία μετακίνησης των ατόμων που τους χορηγήθηκε άσυλο μέσα στην ΕΕ

Για περισσότερες πληροφορίες:

http://www.sos-europe-amnesty.eu/

story:
Summary

  • The Nour Center is a school for over 200 Palestinian and Syrian youth located in the Burj Al-Barajneh refugee camp in Lebanon. The center is currently in urgent need of funds in order to cover its rent, utility costs, and teacher salaries. 
  • If just 200 people donated $1/week, it would completely cover the expenses of the center, for a whole year! 
  • It costs $330 a year to fund a students education at the Nour Center. 
  • We are a group of college students studying across the world who believe in supporting the Nour Center.

Social/Political Context

  • Lebanon has been an escape for Syrian and Palestinian refugees for many years now. Over 1.1 million Syrian refugees and around 450,000 Palestinian refugees currently live across the country, many of them in one of twelve different refugee camps which often suffer from overcrowding and lack of proper healthcare, education, and security.
  • Both Syrian and Palestinian refugees struggle with obtaining jobs in Lebanon due to systematic discrimination against them, as they are often not granted legal working status even after legally settling in the country. Most recently, a law was passed that completely inhibits Syrians and Palestinians without work permits from working, which has sparked public outcry from the refugee communities around the country, as this hasn’t been the case since 1948. 

Children in the camps are, therefore, often left with little opportunity in terms of education and personal development. Young boys are commonly raised by street life, which usually leads to them joining local militias and engaging in drug/substance use. Young girls are often married at a very young age-- within their early teens many times-- often raising one or more children by the time they are 20 years old. 

  • Burj Al-Barajneh Camp:  “[Burj Al-Barajneh] is the most overpopulated refugee camps around Beirut and living conditions are very poor.”-UNRWA Official Report on Burj al Barajneh Refugee Camp.

The camp is located on the outskirts of Beirut, and it currently houses over 50,000 Palestinian and Syrian refugees combined. This is up from an original count of 26,000 before 2011--when the Syrian civil war began and Lebanon experienced an influx of refugees. The camp is known for its unsafe conditions and overcrowding. It suffers from sewage and drainage issues, contains low hanging frayed electrical wires, and is filled with tight, dark, and unclean streets.

What is the Nour Center? 

  • The Nour Center is a informal school for just over 200 Syrian and Palestinian children in the Burj Al-Barajneh refugee camp. The center was founded in 2011 after the beginning of the Syrian Civil war. The center is an informal school for these children as they cannot attend normal public schools or UNRWA funded schools because they have not been granted legal refugee status in Lebanon. Amidst the struggles experienced by both Syrians and Palestinians alike in the camp (and other camps), the WPA and its workers have successfully created a safe haven where both youth and young adults can recognize and achieve their full potential.
  • The center provides education to both Palestinians and Syrians from the ages of 6 to 18 years old (there are young adults from the ages of 18 to 24 also at the school, but they are funded by Anera)*. It provides education and support for just over 200 kids currently, and it only has four active teachers running the classes. Different subjects, including Arabic, English, and Math, are taught by the same teacher in the same classroom from 9 am to 1 pm. The students often arrive early and try their best to stay late at the center or at the WPA building located near the school as it is a place of true peace, calm, and joy.

How/Why is it struggling?

  • The center struggles greatly as it primarily helps children that do not have UN-recognized refugee status, and therefore cannot enter into UNRWA, United Nations Relief and Works Agency, schools. Furthermore, due to recent UNRWA budget cuts, there have been increasingly fewer children allowed to enter UNRWA schools which has added to the pressure on the Nour Center. The primary issue with the Nour Center is that it lacks any real form of long term security. The school is funded almost entirely by donations from individuals (although it has recently been lightly supported by "Anera" and "Kafa", two NGO’s linked below!), and over the past year, there has been a drastic decline in funds, putting the school in immediate risk of shutting down. The school’s yearly total costs are $70,000
  • The center is currently behind on its rent payments due to scarce funds and is therefore at risk of shutting down before the beginning of 2020. 
  • Furthermore, due to recent UNRWA budget cuts, many schools have been decreasing the amount of students they can support which is greatly increasing the demand for help from the center. 

 

How you can help and where your money is going!!!

  • HOW? Any amount of donation is extremely helpful.  
  • WHERE? The account you are donating to is the US based NGO Programs For Palestine, that will be transfering all funds to the WPA financial account. The WPA (Women’s Program Association) is an independent non-governmental, non-profit organization formally established with help from UNRWA in March of 2008 (Lebanese registration number AD344). 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • SPREAD THE WORD!! Spreading awareness about the center and its struggles not only helps the center survive, but it also keeps people aware and active about supporting the struggling refugee communities in Lebanon and throughout the world! Use the hashtag #SaveNour and let your friend and family know! LINKS TO SOCIAL MEDIA BELOW.
  • Visit! If you are in the country, please feel free to visit the center in the camp and learn more about what the WPA does in Burj Al-Barajneh and other camps around Lebanon. Also, if you have any material donations including books, clothes, shoes, toys, etc, please bring them to the center as any help is always appreciated!

For More Information:

  • Women's Program Association: (Head Organization of the Nour Center) https://www.wpa-lebanon.org/
  • UNRWA: (United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East, for Information about the refugee camps and situation in Lebanon)    https://www.unrwa.org
  • Anera: (American Near East Refugee Aid) Offers Large scale humanitarian aid to refugees in Palestine and Lebanon     https://www.anera.org/
  • Kafa: (A Lebanese NGO fighting for Women’s rights and gender equality) https://www.kafa.org.lb/en

Contact/Social Media

Contact us through any of the following social media platforms. We’d love to help answer any questions you may have!

  • Email: womensprogramassociation@gmail.com 
  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/WomensProgramsAssociat...
  • Instagram: womens.programs.association, https://www.instagram.com/womens.programs.assoc...

story:
As the capital of Kabul fell to the Taliban, one of the first signs Sharia Law was being reintroduced was the removal of public billboards and photography of women. 

Their identity is being erased.

We have created this as a way for their images to live on, and save past progress from being forgotten.
It’s not enough, but it’s something. 

Picture Progress is an adult coloring book that recreates and immortalizes these images of Afghan women while also educating people on the uncertainty they now face under Sharia Law.

All the proceeds from the book will go towards Women for Women, a non-profit organization that has established an emergency Women in Afghanistan initiative to help during this impossible time.

 

About Women for Women

Afghanistan is currently one of the most difficult countries in the world in which to identify as a woman. Political and economic insecurity, educational inequality, sexual violence, and poor health are pervasive amongst Afghan women and children, but when equipped with powerful vocational and economic tools, women can change their lives, regardless of circumstance. 

 

Women for Women International has developed a program that offers Afghan women a constructive, dignified way to discover their power. Our foundational training helps women know and defend their rights, lead mentally and physically healthy lives, influence decisions at home and in their communities, generate income, and save money for the future, contributing to economic self-sufficiency in their lives and for their families.

story:
Payday is hitting the road to get into the trenches of the fight to Organize the South.

This winter, we were able to successfully raise our budget for the spring and used a portion of that money to buy a car off of Payday reader Judge Wayne Hanson of Pennsylvania. Now,  we are hitting the road for the next two months and intend to tour ten states. To do this tour, we need to raise $1,500 to pay for our gas, hotel rooms, and food while we are out reporting.

Here is a look at some of the places we intend to go and the stories we hope to cover:

- Canton, Mississippi - Bernie Sanders is flying down to Mississippi to march in solidarity with the NAACP and the UAW which are engaged in a dynamic multi-year campaign to unionize Nissan.

- Huntsville, Alabama - Alabama was once a union stronghold in the Deep South. However, last year, Alabama lost over 37,000 union members while all that states that border Alabama gained union members.

- Nashville, Tennessee - Nashville is growing at nearly 10% a year and experiencing a major construction boom. Yet, most of that work is being done non-union and workers complain that safety on the job is lacking.

- Knoxville, Tennessee - The Republican Governor of Tennessee Bill Haslam is attempting to privatize over 10,000 jobs in the University of Tennessee system. Organized labor and even some Republican legislators are fighting the measure.

- Frankfort, Kentucky - The Kentucky AFL-CIO is meeting to strategize how to adapt to the recently passed “Right-to-Work” law.

- Charleston, West Virginia - Recently proposed cuts to West Virginia Public Broadcasting are being protested by labor and environmentalists in the state.

- Baltimore, Maryland - Democrats in Maryland have been opposing efforts to increase the minimum wage to $15 an hour.

- Washington, D.C. - Payday is going to investigate how labor is responding to the Trump era.

- Danville, Virginia - The small town of Danville was recently rocked by the deaths of four workers at the Goodyear plant. Payday hopes to investigate how the community is responding.

- Raleigh, North Carolina - Despite lacking collective bargaining rights, the North Carolina Public Service Workers Union is making large inroads across the state.

- Charleston, South Carolina - Boeing workers recently lost a union vote at the plant by a margin of 3 to 1. We want to look into how workers intend to keep organizing there.

- Atlanta, Georgia - State Senator Vince Fort is making an insurgent run for Mayor of Atlanta. He has received the support of Bernie Sanders and the area’s labor unions, but is facing heavy opposition from the Democratic Machine.

These are just a few of the planned stops, we have along the way. If you want Payday to come visit your community to do some reporting, just let give us a place to stay and we will come do some reporting.

So folks, help us get out the road and raise $1,500 we need to do this reporting tour

In Solidarity,

Mike Elk, Payday Senior Labor Reporte
