story:
What is GEQUA and What is Our Project?

During our program, Columbia University students will collaborate with Ecuadorian leaders to support indigenous and women's groups in their work to sustain healthy living and just working conditions.

  • GEQUA has been going to Ecuador for more than 5 years, working with FBU, a local NGO headed by Ecuadorian leadership
  • GEQUA engages in both long-term and short-term projects which the community emphasizes are critical to their development and progress

By donating to this campaign, you will contribute greatly to an irrigation project that will bring economic independence to more than 250 families in rural Ecuador.  

  • The drought in Ecuador this year has devasted crops, thus raising food prices, and destroying the livelihoods of many indigenous subsistence farmers.
  • Women in particular are severely affected (see more in "Impact" below)
  • The irrigation system will allow them to be more successful independent from the fluctuations of weather.

Thanks to everyone who donated to Part I of our fundraising during our first campaign! See more here: www.indiegogo.com/gequaecuador

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need to raise $8,000 this year.  This money will go towards the irrigation project mentioned above as well as the sustainability of the program so that we can continue to make increasingly effective contributons in our partnership with the Ecuadorian community.
  • We want you, our supporters to really feel like you are part of our community and our movement to increase cross-cultural solidarity.  To this end, we have a blog where we post regular updates about our preparation to ensure thoughtful service. Also, if you donate $50 or more, we include you on our List of Friends on this website.  

The Impact

This year, we focus on understanding and supporting alternatives for women forced by economic circumstances to work in harmful rose plantations.  

  • These women come into contact with pesticides every day that cause cancer, lead to physically and mentally disabled children, and even barrenness, all within 3-5 years.
  • These women are already finding solutions like starting organic rose farms, and feeding themselves through their own community development
  • The irrigation project mentioned above will bring water to their fields so that they are successful in their independent endeavors.
  • Help us support them by donating whatever you can.  Every dollar counts.  

The Program Model

Our model challenges students to engage head-on at the cross-section of scholarly engagement (thought) and responsible international service (action). Most of our group members have participated in some form of service in the past, but part of GEQUA’s mission is to create service whose impact is both relevant to the needs of the community and sustainable for future years.

  • a. Pre-departure training

The 12 students accepted into the program devote at least 5 hours a week to plan,
fundraise, and undergo training. Participants understand the context of gender equality issues in both the US and Ecuador through a pre-trip curriculum over a period of 10 weeks before departing for spring break. Speakers for the pre-trip program include past participants, University professors and staff members with extensive international research and service experience, as well as members of local NGOs. By inviting other local actors (i.e., other university students, international organizations, and other non-governmental organizations) to participate in program components, students initiate relationships that support an international network of leaders.  Additionally, each student takes up responsibility to hold at least one fundraiser.

  • b. Service trip to Ecuador

During the week long trip, students partner with local leaders and community members to experience women’s work through community service projects, talks, workshops, and mingas. Every day, we meet with a different woman leader to discuss issues pertaining to her specific line of work. Our community service projects complement these interactions by exposing our group to concrete realities and needs: working on family farms; supporting our partner organization’s efforts in re-forestation and organic tree farming; assisting on the eco-agricultural hacienda; volunteering at the local school and infant center; and empowering alternatives for women and children to escape the rose plantation industry.

  • c. Post-trip Symposium:

After the service trip, participants hold a forum about the experiences in Ecuador and
about what they learned. The purpose of the forum is to teach other Columbia students and administrators about their experiences/ what was learned and about future projects and potential partnerships in Ecuador.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come to our events!
  • Like us on facebook:https://www.facebook.com/GequaEcuador
  • Read our blog:http://gequa2013.blogspot.com/

During our program, Columbia University students will collaborate with Ecuadorian leaders to support indigenous and women's groups in their work to sustain healthy living and just working conditions.

GEQUA has been going to Ecuador for more than 5 years, working with FBU, a local NGO headed by Ecuadorian leadership
GEQUA engages in both long-term and short-term projects which the community emphasizes are critical to their development and progress

By donating to this campaign, you will contribute greatly to an irrigation project that will bring economic independence to more than 250 families in rural Ecuador.  

The drought in Ecuador this year has devasted crops, thus raising food prices, and destroying the livelihoods of many indigenous subsistence farmers.
Women in particular are severely affected (see more in "Impact" below)

story:
Homeless Veterans across America currently number in the tens of thousands. According to CNN, 22 veterans commit suicide everyday! These numbers are staggering and unacceptable.

In order to make a long-lasting permanent change in an individual's life, there must be a change  in the way the brain responds to life. This is precisely what my books accomplish. 

My goal is to provide every homeless veteran with a Free copy of "A Good Brain Washing" and "Affirmations: For Every Area of Life" to help them move forward in their lives and restore their hope. www.talpub.com 

The Arizona StandDown is the state's largest, outreach event for homeless veterans...to gain access to shelter, services, and healthcare. The Maricopa County event served...homeless and at-risk veterans...1,510 in 2013. see www.arizonastanddown.org for more info.


Will you please help me? Any size donation is greatly appreciated. Even $1 will go towards the purchase of a book for a Veteran. 

The picture is of me working as a volunteer at the Arizona StandDown held in the Coliseum in Phoenix in 2013.

story:
Where Your Donation Goes

Funds raised will directly support Afrischa, Agun, Awan, Syahrial, Zainal, their families, and Azwar's family.

Other Donation Options

You can also donate directly to the Innocent Cleaners' Indonesian bank account.  Please send an email to innocentcleaners@gmail.com for bank transfer information.

Their Story

In March of 2014, the mother of a kindergarten child attending Jakarta Intercultural School (JIS formerly Jakarta International School) disclosed that her son had been molested by the janitorial staff (cleaners) hired to maintain the school’s buildings and grounds.

On March 28th, probably with help, her son identified Agun Iskander, Awan Amin, and Afrischa Setyani. It was almost a month later that Syahrial, Zainal Abidin and Azwar’s names were added. (It should be noted that many Indonesian men identify themselves with a single name.)  All of the accused were responsible for financially supporting themselves as well as members of their families.  What the mother didn’t know was that two of the identified cleaners were substitutes on the day of identification and regularly worked a completely different part of the campus, and therefore were not present through the time the mother declared the offenses had taken place.

Yet the evidence was ignored, the cleaners were taken into custody, and lo and behold, several confessed. Under normal, civil circumstances that might have cast a pall over the above declaration that no crime was committed.  However witnesses said the confessions were extracted through torture.  Azwar, who did not confess, died in custody on the day of his interrogation.  Police claim he committed suicide by drinking cleaning fluid that he found in a bathroom in the investigator’s’ office, but witnesses declared his face and body were battered.  It is likely the others confessed to stay alive.  Afrischa, the only female, did not confess, but she was the only one with legal counsel and was therefore the only one not tortured.  The surviving cleaners tried to recant their confessions when they got to what they thought was the relative safety of the court, but the recantations were rejected and they were each sentenced to eight years in prison, while Afrischa received seven.

The JIS community, the innocent cleaners’ family, friends, supporters around the world, and several Indonesian human rights organizations believe that Agun, Afrischa, Awan, Syahrial, Zainal, and the deceased Azwar are innocent, and have been wrongfully convicted of crimes which all credible evidence shows never occurred.  Therefore, we will continue to support them morally, legally, and financially until they find justice.

More On The Injustice in Jakarta

Justice for All - The life stories of Agun, Awan, Syahrial, and Zainal and what it is like for them in prison

Wrongful Conviction - Afrischa's story: the one female unjustly convicted

story:
A little backstory first…

My name is Anjali Alwis. I graduated from Syracuse University in 2017 with a degree in TV, Radio, Film and have been working in all three of those departments over the past two years.

I will be going to three refugee camps in Lebanon for eight days with MedGlobal. In that time, we will be shooting three pieces: two shorter pieces that highlight the important work that MedGlobal is doing, and a longer documentary.

The two shorter videos are focused on how MedGlobal is combating health disparity through the remarkable work being done by doctors, nurses, and volunteers, it’s partnerships with local organizations, and it’s focus on a sustainable impact.

The third project is a longer documentary about the camps and the people in them. I went on a mission Summer 2016 to Thessaloniki, Greece and was overwhelmed, saddened and inspired by the stories I heard of everyday life; of the mother who was an accomplished artist in Syria, a daughter who dreamed of being a pilot, a friend who only had two years left until a college degree in teaching. I'd like this documentary to focus on how devastating it is, not just for the individual but society at large, when talented, bright, passionate individuals are forced to put their lives on hold, waiting in a refugee camp.

What We Need 

Our Budget:

The first $2,500 raised towards this will go towards these projects for MedGlobal: equipment, production costs, and actual travel expenses. Any money raised over our budget will be donated directly to MedGlobal. This money is used to purchase medications, surgical supplies, nutritional supplements, toiletries and clothing for refugees in the camps in Lebanon.

Some numbers are a rough estimate as we are waiting on a complete itinerary. This page will be updated accordingly.

Equipment: we are finalizing what equipment we are renting, once we have the exact price determined I will update this. The list below is a general overview of what we would be renting.  

  • Equipment (Camera, microphones, lights): $800
  • Production Supplies: $150. 
  • Media Storage: $150. 
  • Insurance/Liability: $1000
  • Total Cost: About $2100

Hotel Fees: MedGlobal books the hotels in advance

  • Hotel fee for nine nights: $900

Miscellaneous:

  • Meals for 2 people, 8 days: $250

Overall Cost: Currently it would be between $2,000 - 3,000. 

The Impact

Two years ago, while on a medical mission in Greece, I wrote, edited, and produced (with the guidance of WAER and WWFM) a six-part series, “Six Degrees of Separation” that was picked up on stations across the United States. Each segment tells the tales of different people and issues from the refugee camp, their arduous and dangerous journeys in a search for safety.  The stories of those affected, and those trying to help, are told largely in their own words, with creative production using poetry and music.

You can listen to the full piece here: https://www.waer.org/post/six-degrees-separatio...

You can also read the article I wrote about the refugee camps for a Syracuse website here: https://thetab.com/us/syracuse/2016/09/30/just-...

"Before [that] summer I never thought I could connect to their situation. I couldn’t imagine being told I have 30 minutes to evacuate my home. To simply run. Nothing in hand, nothing more to my name than the clothes on my back. Hearing that last week my brother had been shot at a peaceful protest. Remembering last night when my husband had been pulled out of our bed, pushed into the trunk of a car and driven off.

What would I tell my children as they cried through nightly bombings? How would you convince them to go to school when they have seen people being shot at checkpoints? How do you tell a child they do not get to be a child any longer?

...This is the reality for millions and millions of people today. It is a completely unfathomable situation but the people are so, so much more relatable than I ever thought they could be"

This campaign is important on two counts.

  1. The MedGlobal team deserves recognition for the work they are doing in responding to humanitarian crises all over the world and these two videos will help them get the word out about the crises going on, what can be done, and how they specifically are helping. https://www.medglobal.org/
  2. It’s important to remember who is being affected by this crisis. It’s the 18 year old that was about to start college, or the eight year old that hasn’t seen their dad in years. It’s easy to detach from this tragedy when people are grouped together as “refugees”; the people living this reality become statistics on a TV screen. But the hard to bear reality is that trapped in these refugee camps are an immeasurable number of bright, passionate, motivated people who could do so much. 

Why Donate? 

You might be reading this and wondering why you should donate to this campaign when you can donate directly to the organizations.

This campaign is important because telling the stories of refugees and non-profits like MedGlobal helps to get the word out. It keeps them in the public eye and forces the world to think deeply about this humanitarian crisis. And in turn, even more people are inspired to care, donate, and make change.

If you're reading this and feeling like you would like to give directly, great! Links below to donate directly to two organizations that are helping refugees (there are many but I know the work done by these ones).

https://www.medglobal.org/donate

https://donate.unhcr.org/gb/general/~my-donatio...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute funds, that doesn't mean you can't help! Help me get the word out and make some noise about the campaign by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or any other social media you use.

If you're reading this and feeling like you would like to give directly, great! Links below to donate directly to two organizations that are helping refugees (there are many but I know the work done by these ones).
https://www.medglobal.org/donate

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute funds, that doesn't mean you can't help! Help me get the word out and make some noise about the campaign by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or any other social media you use.

story:
What is this Unlimited Possibilities Fund?

It's summertime again, and you know what that means in Austin.  It means Barton Springs.  It means fireworks.  It means Rock 'n Roll.  Girls Rock Camp Austin is back in session!

We've been providing the summertime ROCK in Austin since 2007, empowering girls to learn new instruments, write original songs, and perform live on some of the best stages that Austin has to offer (Emo's, Antone's, Spider House Ballroom, and the ND just to name a few). During the year, we keep up with the camper bands by supporting their various gigs and providing a whole day of music at the Girls Rock Camp SXSW Unofficial Day Party.

This summer, we're offering another three full weeks of camp, as well as junior camp.  Your donations to the Unlimited Possibilities Fund will set the stage for another wonderful year of music education programming, volunteer magnificence, and community building.


Our Priorities:


1. Scholarships:

Full fare girls rock camp tuition is $400.00.  The first $4,000.00 of this campaign will go directly into the Esme Barrera Unlimited Possibilities Scholarship Fund to provide full Girls Rock Austin scholarships to 10 girls who otherwise wouldn't be able to afford to come to camp. About half of the girls who attend camp every year are awarded scholarships based on financial need, and we are committed to being accessible. We strive to maintain our status as an organization that will never turn away any girl who wants to go to camp due to financial constraints.  

2. Gear:

As you can see in the video, we are in serious need of working gear. We teach campers how to use their own instruments and basic sound equipment so that they become self-sufficient and confident both on-stage and with their gear.  

Everything, from drum sticks to strings to amps, is provided by our generous donors and the volunteer musicians themselves. We’ve doubled our program in the last year, and our gear is key to the success of the program.

After the scholarships are funded, here is where your money will go:

  • 6 sets of cymbals (approx $2400 total)
  • 3 drum kits (approx $1000/ea)
  • 2 PAs (approx $500/ea)
  • guitar and bass cases (approx $250 total)
  • 4 guitars ($200/ea)
  • 4 basses ($200/ea)


The Impact

By providing a positive, all-female environment that offers musical instruction as well as a variety of workshops and performances, the camp creates leadership opportunities, cultivates a supportive community of peers and mentors, and encourages social change and the development of life skills.

Come to any one of our showcases and see firsthand what kind of community this creates for girls - you will walk away with high spirits and a renewed sense of hope for our future.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Be a volunteer!  Visit our camp page to fill out an application and become part of the team.
  • Spread the word! Share this campaign with everyone you know on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
  • Come to a showcase at the ND on July 26th or August 9th!

6 sets of cymbals (approx $2400 total)
3 drum kits (approx $1000/ea)
2 PAs (approx $500/ea)
guitar and bass cases (approx $250 total)

4 guitars ($200/ea)

4 basses ($200/ea)
The ImpactBy providing a positive, all-female environment that offers musical instruction as well as a variety of workshops and performances, the camp creates leadership opportunities, cultivates a supportive community of peers and mentors, and encourages social change and the development of life skills.Come to any one of our showcases and see firsthand what kind of community this creates for girls - you will walk away with high spirits and a renewed sense of hope for our future.Other Ways You Can Help
Be a volunteer!  Visit our camp page to fill out an application and become part of the team.

Spread the word! Share this campaign with everyone you know on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
Come to a showcase at the ND on July 26th or August 9th!

story:
We can't close the campaign until the official end date but the hat is now full so consider it unofficially closed. Thank you to everyone who donated and boosted this online. We are just floored by the power that a community has to help each other. Big love to everyone.

Operation Eviction Intervention

Our friend and neighbour is having a mental health crisis that has brought him very close to being evicted. If evicted, it is likely he will be homeless. We are not sharing his name in order to respect his privacy, but we can tell you that he is a considerate and kind person who has grown up in this community, and who has been suffering from the death of a close family member.

Mental illness is a major contributor to homelessness, and as many of you know, our social "safety net" does not help everyone, or help them soon enough. We have 8 days to raise enough money to keep our friend from being homeless. He is looking into all avenues to raise the money but the challenge is in the time limit — 8 days is not enough time to get onto disability benefits, and because of how low disability rates are, that will not be enough to get him through this immediate danger.

We have already passed the hat among our own immediate community, and now need to ask our larger communities to consider helping our friend out. We have a chance to keep someone from becoming homeless. If you can kick in a few bucks, we'd be grateful, and I know our friend will be too.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $2700. This will cover the $1800 he needs to pay in order to have his eviction revoked, plus $600 for his November rent, plus $300 to cover the Indiegogo fees and currency conversion. This will get our friend out of immediate danger of eviction so he can get past this crisis and focus on his health.

This campaign is flexible-funded so after Indiegogo and payment fees are covered, 100% of the money we raise goes towards our friend's rent, whether or not we reach our goal. 

The perk is: helping to prevent someone in crisis from becoming homeless. That's a huge perk!

    We are tired of seeing vulnerable people in our community land on the street and we have a chance to intervene to prevent this from happening to a fellow community member.

    We also understand that many more in our larger communities are struggling, and can't necessarily contribute financially. Sharing this campaign with others is another way to help out our friend. Thank you for whatever you can do to help!

    In solidarity and love,
    Caroline Boback, Erin Kastner, Marilyn Larson, Alanna Makabe, Setareh Mohammadi, Terra Poirier, Malgorzata Sienkiewicz

story:
Short Summary

 

Im Sylvia Agyeiwaa, I am a senior at Fitchburg State University, majoring in Comm media. Im working with Morgan Wynkoop (Director and Producer), Trevor Cormier(Editor & Sound Mixer), Brendan Manning(Director of Photography), Nyelah Aidoo(Assistant Editor & Researcher), Zsamir Brenard (Lighting & Research) who are also seniors at Fitchburg State University, also Comm Media majors. 

    Voices of the Past and Present is a film that encapsulates the struggles, work, dedication, and growing involvement in humanitarian efforts to change the way the United States has ignored police brutality towards the African American community and the changing of the Judicial system. Our goal of this film is to enlighten and bring awareness to Black Lives Matter, and the dedication to getting justice for the Black and Brown lives taken over the years. By showcasing the movement we plan on educating our audience on racism and discrimination and how the African American community is affected by the history of this country. We also want to share the raw emotion of those that work endlessly to bring these peaceful protests and rallies to life. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We would need about $350
  • The money would be going towards the costs of rights for archival footage. 
  • Paying fees for festivals and other film distributors
  • Cover expenses for equipment that might be needed while working on the documentary remotely.

The Impact

As a crew, and the next generation of leaders is it important for us to help lead change. The impact we want to leave with our audience is to get them to think, observe, and reflect on the human rights issue of Police Brutality in the United States. 

  • It would be valuable to you and many others with the message, and theme we convey to push an understanding of Police Brutality
  • Be part of a time where the youth of today  can rise and make a change and impact others through our message

Risks & Challenges

  • We understand the condition we are currently in. Being in a pandemic is hard.
    We plan on following CDC guidelines by wearing a mask and staying 6 feet from everyone.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can follow us on Instagram to keep up with updates and more @voicesofpastandpresent_  

  • Spread the word to friends and families. Your support is appreciated.

story:
UPDATE (February 5, 2020): Just before Christmas, Rebel News sent Sheila Gunn Reid to Iraqi Kurdistan to document the plight of Christian and Yazidi refugees receiving aid from The Nazarene Fund.

When we released our footage and interviews with these refugees, we started a fundraiser with a modest goal to raise $10,000 to help support the effort.

And with your help, we were able to raise over $30,000!

But our journey is not quite over. We still need to cover the costs of Sheila’s journalism in Iraq — her flights alone totalled over $2,000. 

Please click here to help us cover the cost of Sheila's journey to bring you these stories.

Thank you.

 

UPDATE: We've hit our initial goal, but let's keep it going!

In less than 24 hours, we have already hit our initial goal. 

But let's not stop just yet. 

All funding will go to The Nazarene Fund, so please continue to donate on this important project! 

Merry Christmas! 

 

Rebel News has teamed up with The Nazarene Fund to raise money for the Christian refugees in Syria and Iraq. That’s one of the world’s most ancient Christian communities — they even still pray in Aramaic, the language Jesus himself spoke.

But Iraq’s Christians are in grave jeopardy — first, from the genocide perpetrated by ISIS terrorists, and now by other Muslim extremists, including those supported by Iran.

Sheila Gunn Reid of Rebel News recently travelled to Iraq to meet some of these Christian families first-hand, and to inspect the work done by the registered charity, The Nazarene Fund. You can see her video reports here.

But it’s not enough just to tell their story — we need to help.

Please join our Christmas campaign to raise $10,000 to help rescue and relocate these Christian families. 100% of the proceeds will support The Nazarene Fund’s projects that Sheila personally observed in action. If we meet our $10,000 goal, we’ll aim higher — there is so much work that has to be done.

And if you support Sheila’s journalism, please click here, to contribute to a separate journalism fund, to cover the costs of her flight to Iraq — which totalled just over $2,000. We are keeping the two funds separate — this one on Indiegogo is solely for the Christian relief, and this one is for our costs, including travel to Iraq.

Thank you — and Merry Christmas to all.

story:
I cannot change my storyfrom year to year because this IS my story~~

From the very first time I saw homeless people (DC) It broke my heart. To see people sleeping on the ground, on benches, going thru garbage cans was simply heartbreaking. Alot of them were homeless Vets and mentally Ill who were turned out on the street after the facility closed in Virginia.

After seeing this I gave away all the blankets and sheets I owned and started making sack lunches (bologna sandwiches, chips, 2 cookies, and a napkin) loaded 50 of them in my clothes basket and delivered them every sunday morning.

After awhile I actually became friends with many of them and they would be waiting for me each sunday. One Sunday so many were there .. I ran out of food. I quickly drove to Mcdonalds and bought enough sausage and biscuits to feed the remaining croud. That was the last Sunday I gave away my bags...I realized i couldn't afford to feed every hungry person each week. I had bigger plans.

Fast forward about 20 years and the less fortunate are still my passion. I do know the difference in the different stages of homelessness, the junkys, the alcholics..none of this matters to me..I like to feed them all!

What started with fixing and giving away maybe 20 plates to the homeless many years ago..has turned into 188-230 plates each Thanksgiving and another 200 + plates at Christmas along with 35 boxes of food for families who would like to cook their own holiday dinner. Last year I started something new. I found some of the neediest families and got the kids underwear, socks, undershirts, gloves, hats, and coats. it was wonderful! Also had a friend who sent me some things from his store that i rapped and gave them to some women in the neighborhood ( who normally would have nothing). This is the time of year to give to others. I have always believed this and am trying so hard to do more each year. This is why I need your help!!!

I have always funded this myself but learned about indiegogo 2 years ago and launched a campaign! Thanks to my wonderful contributors last year i was able to make between 188-230 plates for thanksgiving and at christmas another 200+ plates, 35 boxes of food and clothing for 5 entire families and their children!!!, I am hoping i can raise enough to do even more this year.

I am hoping some of you may share this passion with me and help me make this the biggest holiday to date!!! THis will be the 8th year I have done this! Each year, I'm happy to say, has been even more successful than the year before!

Also, I'm the one taking all the pics !!! Thats why i am not in them, lol..when i do this i love to be completely alone with music going..i do not want friends to help me because, sometimes, they do not put love into it..and i do!!! I do have to to have help with delivering them ;)

Help me make this the biggest year yet..and feed even more than last year!

I want to thank any of you, in advance, who share my passion and will help me!

story:
THANK YOU ALL FOR VISITING, DONATING AND SHARING!

With your help, the help of Indiegogo and the help of our chapters and members we have been able to raise 9100$ for our campaign!  This is more than we could ever have hoped for!

For those of you who requested perks... (100$ or more donations, and 300$ or more donations) we we will be getting them to you AS SOON AS THEY BECOME AVAILABLE.

These Children will be arriving at camp in the next few days, thanks to all of your help!

Again, THANK YOU ALL!

---------------------------------
 Please help us send as may displaced children as possible to camp this summer!

Give the gift of summer camp to an Internally Displaced Child in Ukraine this summer!

Dear Friends,

While we have reached our minimum target for this campaign, we are sill quite a way from our goal committed by the Ukrainian Youth Association of Canada to ensure the success of this camp.  With less than 20 hours left in our campaign and 6 days left until camp begins we ask that you continue to donate and share our campaign to help us reach and surpass this goal of  $6000CAD mark so that the maximum number of children can attend this summer camp in August and so that we can cover the costs of our campaign!

---

Each summer The Ukrainian Youth Association runs summer camps across the globe for youth and for all ages. 

However this summer is different.  Ukraine is fighting a war in its’ Eastern Regions and 100,000’s of children have lost their homes or have been relocated away from their friends. Many have fathers and/or mothers on the front, and some have lost parents or loved ones in this war. According to a recent UNICEF report, over 1.7 million children have been affected by this war. It is for this reason that UYA has decided to run a camp for these children in Ukraine. 

The camp will be held in the Chernihiv province of Ukraine, under the watchful eye of volunteers from across the globe, traveling at their own expense to support these children.  Camp dates are from August 9 to 22.

The adult to child ratio for the camp will be no more than 1 to 10 children to one supervisor.  It is our hope to be able to fund camp attendance for 75 children from across Ukraine.

The cost to send a single child to camp for 2 weeks is: 300CAD. This cost includes 3 meals, and 2 snacks, travel costs for campers and any and all activities planned for the camp. The Canadian Ukrainian Youth Association has committed to a minimum donation of 4000$ to ensure that the camp runs smoothly and as many possible children can attend.  If we are able to raise more than this amount, we can add additional activities to the program!

Planned activities at camp include:

Sports activities, arts and crafts, health and wellness, singing, and an opportunity for these children to relax and make new and, hopefully, lifelong friends!

We ask you to visit the updates section of  our  campaign page as we will be posting additional information there as it becomes available. 

Information about the Ukrainian Youth Association, and about this camp can be found here.  If you are unable to donate but wish to contribute in another way, please email us.

Should you have any questions or concerns, please contact the Ukrainian Youth Association of Canada at:

1.416.537.2007

Ky-canada@cym.org

or, in Ukrainian only, The Ukrainian Youth Association in Ukraine at:

http://cym.org/ua/pro-sum-v-ukrayini/

Contact information for other branches of the UYA can be found at here. Please choose the country that interests you at the top right hand side of the page.

We do ask you to note that tax receipts for these donations will not be available as the funds collected are being used outside of Canada and our charitable status does not apply for international donations.

story:
Дорогие друзья, в прошлом году мы на праздник Рамазан устроили благотворительную акцию. Благодаря вашей помощи, получилось собрать средства в размере 1305 манат. Мы сумели посетить около 10 семей, пообщались, а также передали необходимые товары и средства. Подробнее о результатах акции и фотографии можете найти здесь:

https://www.facebook.com/events/259444227585951/permalink/269180439945663/

После акции у нас осталось 607 манат. 
В четверг, 9 июля, мы посетили семью Нурлана. Ему 24 года, у него врожденные проблемы с мышцами - он не может ходить. Нурлан очень позитивный человек, любит футбол, может использовать компьютер. Живет со своей матерью. Но есть кое что, на что у его семьи не хватает денег. Это электронная коляска. На нынешней коляске он не может двигаться без помощи матери, нет никаких средств торможения, поворачивания и движения спинки. В специальной аптеке (на пр. Азадлыг, около Травмотологической больницы) мы нашли коляску за 1150 манат и хотели бы ее купить для Нурлана. Изначально она стоила 1500 манат, но узнав об акции, магазин скинул 350 манат. 
Мы приглашаем вас помочь собрать оставшиеся средства и подарить радость Нурлану и его семье.

Чтобы оказать помощь, нужно на этом сайте нажать на CONTRIBUTE NOW и следовать инструкциям.

Азадлыг, около Травмотологической больницы) мы нашли коляску за 1150 манат и хотели бы ее купить для Нурлана. Изначально она стоила 1500 манат, но узнав об акции, магазин скинул 350 манат. Мы приглашаем вас помочь собрать оставшиеся средства и подарить радость Нурлану и его семье.Чтобы оказать помощь, нужно на этом сайте нажать на CONTRIBUTE NOW и следовать инструкциям.

story:
JUST £5 OR £10 CAN HELP SEND A PINK BUS TO CALAIS!


On June 18th there will be a large convoy visiting the refugee camp in Calais, delivering aid and solidarity. 

We are a coalition of LGBT+ groups and activists who oppose this government’s actions in refusing entry to those fleeing war and poverty. 

Like them, we know what it’s like to be treated as outsiders. Like us, they just want somewhere to feel safe. 

We have been inspired by the actions of the Lesbians and Gays Support the Miners group, as featured in the film Pride, who donated a pink van to the pickets during the miners’ strike of 1984/5. In that spirit, we will be taking a Pink Bus to Calais delivering a message of friendship and solidarity. 

The bus will then tour various Pride events around the UK raising awareness of the plight of the refugees, before being donated to a charity working to deliver aid directly to the camps.

 We are relying entirely on donations to make this possible – no amount is too small or too large! Even £5 or £10 will help if enough of us give! Please give what you can, and raise this in all of your networks, trade unions and campaign groups. Even if you can't donate money you can help by sharing this page on facebook and twitter.

If you would like a speaker for a fund-raising event please get in touch with any of the groups on this page.

UPDATE

LGBT+ Support Refugees and Migrants and LGBT+ Against Islamophobia joined the convoy to Calais on June 18th, bringing aid to the camps. Outrageously we were refused entry at the port of Dover, where a strong protest was called before moving back to the French Embassy in London. Meanwhile some LGBT+ supporters from Birmingham and Wakefield made it through and brought with them, among other things, some prayer beads and mats for young people to celebrate Eid in the camps in July. After Orlando we will not allow homophobes or Islamophobes to win. United we stand divided we fall. Please continue to support the Pink Bus to Calais campaign to bring practical solidarity to the refugees and migrants from LGBT+ people.

story:
During these unprecedented times, life has become really difficult for some folks to feed themselves (e.g. 18,000+ students in Oakland rely on their school for 2+ meals each day, not to mention folks who can’t work right now), and many rely on food banks around their communities to get their daily bread and be fed.

 

The Alameda County Community Food Bank desperately needs resources to do what they need to do to help people get fed. Let's come together to help get funds to the Alameda County Community Food Bank so they can get folks fed!

Be safe out there folks, wash ya hands, stay inside (if you can) and remember that we’re all in this together!

story:
About StoryMuse

Founded in 2016 in the wake of the presidential election, StoryMuse is a storytelling practice dedicated to helping people tell their stories across lines of difference. My mission is to provide unique strategies for personal, business, organizational, community and content development—everywhere it is needed.

The partner for this project, Chris 180, whose mission is to heal children, strengthen families and build community, has been at the forefront of behavioral health and child welfare service delivery since 1981.

What We Need

This project was originally funded by Alternate ROOTS, an arts & social justice network organization that serves the U.S. South. We are so grateful for the support through their Project Development program.

However, when we made the original proposal, we had no idea how much the world would change. Originally conceived as a once-a-week for seven weeks program with a huge performance for the public, now we're creatively pivoting. In order to do this project under safe social distancing practices, we need to:

  • rent a tent so we can have the whole program in one week outside
  • rent equipment so we can create an outdoor drive-in theatre experience where people can experience participants' stories 
  • hire a videographer so that we can record and edit their stories in advance but in a super quick fashion.

What You Get

  • my undying love and respect
  • the knowledge that you've helped these young people tell their powerful stories in a very powerful way
  • first peek at the stories and photos that come out of this project
  • donors over $100 will receive a personal story from me

The Impact

Those of you who've been following my work for a while know the therapeutic benefit and spiritual growth inherent in these kinds of projects...

  • I’ve seen it in the work around reflection, resilience, and response at Virginia Tech after the shootings.
  • I felt it to my core in the opportunity to coach Anne, a Maasai young woman from Sub-saharan Africa, a victim of female genital mutilation, who wanted to tell her story to raise awareness about the physical and psychological trauma of FGM.
  • It was embedded in the light and darkness that co-existed in working with girls who’d been sex-trafficked at Devereux. 
  • It was there in the deep and meaningful Truth & Consequences.

Risks & Challenges

To be completely transparent, I have some fear that the performance may not happen for weather and logistical reasons. However, we will still be able to pivot to an online/digital experience that you can enjoy and, most importantly, that the participants can feel proud of. The more support we get on the front end, the more we'll be able to plan and hopefully avoid the hiccups.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially? I totally get it. I will also need volunteer support (both virtually and in person) to make this project happen, so please feel free to reach out if you've got some extra time.

story:
Image Source: Glenn Petty

 

We are Monica & Samantha.  We are sisters-in-law, and in Haiti we'll be sisters in service.  Together we are donating our time, our skills, and our love to help the people of northern Haiti.

We are pooling our resources to go the poorest country in the western hemisphere, putting a halt to the busyness of our lives here in the US, taking time from work, and raising the funds to get us there and to supply our mission.

The Northern Haiti Hope Foundation is based in Warrenton, Virginia and operates on the motto of "this community for that community."  For us, it goes deeper: this family for those families.  Your donation can help us help others.  There is hope in northern Haiti, please help us get there.

 

About your donation:

Your donation will help us cover the cost of travel, basic accommodation, and materials for serving the people of Terrier Rouge, Haiti.  The trip is scheduled for 21-28 October 2012, and will focus primarily on supporting the local school, clinic, and orphanage.  In addition, we will help distribute food to the very needy and determine the next steps for reducing the spread of cholera through providing access to clean drinking water. 

 

What are the goals of the Northern Haiti Hope Foundation?

  • Furthering the efforts of Pere Bruno in educating over 800 children at Saint Barthelemy School in Terrier Rouge and supporting the adjacent Esperance et Vie medical clinic.
  • Employing local villagers to prepare water wells in remote areas that have been decimated with cholera due a lack of access to clean water. 
  • Distributing food and nourishment to the aging citizens still living in abandoned factory towns along northern coast.
  • Supporting the Kay Anj Orphanage in the city of Cap Haitien (helpinghaitianangels.org).

For more, visit northernhaitihope.org

Why Northern Haiti?

  • Haiti is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world. It has struggled with problems ranging from near-constant political upheaval, health crises, an annual barrage of hurricanes and the worst earthquake in the region in more than 200 years.
  • With our help, there is hope.  In this province of Haiti, there are those making a differnce for their own community.  This is how lasting change happens - from the ground up - and it's within this mission that we find hope. 

How can I help?

  • Donate!  
  • Help get the word out about this foundation. 
  • Volunteer - contact info@northernhaitihope.org.

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR GENEROUS SUPPORT!!!

 

THIS COMMUNITY FOR THAT COMMUNITY.  Northern Haiti Hope Foundation.

story:
Short Summary

Betty Louise and Susan M. Davis have been  on the forefront of giving "Voice" to people and topics considered "edgy" or marginal since meeting, virtually, in 2009 when they each produced and hosted their own radio shows on Internet radio networks.

Thanks to serendipity, they both relocated to Nevada County, California in 2015, and became real neighbors, in the same rural, small-town community, and able to spend time co-creating with their CoPassions, which includes StoryCatching with KVMR 89.5FM Community Radio in Nevada City, California. Both Susan and Betty Louise have their own stories about homelessness, and are committed to igniting awareness and shifting perceptions about the homeless community and promoting collaborative, compassionate solutions.

Our Team of CoCreators – the artists, themselves - are equally as important as the two Project Directors. Everyone on the team has a personal story and connection to homelessness. Some have been homeless themselves, or have family members or friends who have been homeless. For all, this connection to homelessness is the driver for their passion and artistic expression in whatever media they choose to work.

 

The money raised here will be used to produce the “A Place To Call Home” Documentary Film, Music CD,  Daily Compassionate Action Calendar, and a free live, experiential public Multi-Media Event in November at the Center For the Arts in Grass Valley, CA. Each of these products or expressions will include and integrate the work of all our participating artists.

We believe that together we can co-create a collaborative movement , powerfully communicating through Story and the Arts,  giving voice to You, Me, Them and  US.

Our vision is to co-create a model for the inclusive world in which we all wish to live.

With this model, and your help, we can make a difference for homeless people, those working with homeless people, and communities struggling with the many issues of homelessness.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our vision is B I G ! We have lots to do, and it will take about $100,000 in 2017 to do it right.

We've already begun, and have partnered with KVMR Community Radio in Nevada City, California. We've received the Humanities for All Quick Grant from California Humanities to seed the project. We've also applied for the Arts & Media Grant from California Arts Council, and will find out if we are a recipient at the end of June. The roots have taken hold, and we've been growing now for eight months. We need your help so A-Place-To-Call-Home can blossom and influence communities everywhere!

Perks for You - Perks for ALL of Us!

We have co-created some great perks and are excited about how they include all of our individual artists and benefit  some of our wonderful non-profit partners - the grass-roots organizations in Nevada County, California serving the homeless community.

Here are a few examples:

Brendan Phillips is a musician, singer/songwriter and a social worker with Turning Point Community Programs, working with chronically homeless folks who also have mental health issues, addictions, and are cycling through our jail. Brendan is also the son of the late U.Utah Phillips, a storyteller, folksinger, and activist who cared deeply about homeless people, and was one of the founders of Hospitality House Community Shelter in Nevada County, CA. Brendan is producing the "A-Place-To-Call-Home" music CD, which has original music created just for this project along with some Utah favorites.

Listen here for a taste of what's to come on this CD. You can also hear Brendan in the Audio Stories on our website.

 
We have some incredibly talented fine-art photographers on our team. Twelve of their photographs will be featured on the 2018 Compassionate Action Calendar we are creating, and you will proudly hang it on your wall. Every day in 2018 will have a "compassionate action" noted, like "Look into the eyes of a homeless person, and say Hello".  By taking these simple acts of kindness and compassion toward our fellow humans, we will create a world filled with Humans Being Positively Human.
 

Franceska Alexander is a talented painter and the owner of The Alexander Gallery in Nevada City, California. Her paintings will be on display at the Center For The Arts in November, as part of the "A Place To Call Home" Project. Sierra Roots, one of the non-profit organizations working with the chronically homeless folks living in the woods in Nevada County, has produced beautiful card-sets with the images of four of these paintings on the fronts of the cards.  Contributors of  $1000 or more, will receive a set of these cards, and we will donate $100 to Sierra Roots, designated to the fund for purchasing property for the sustainable, supportive community of micro-homes that is their vision to build.


And, of course, YOU benefit with these thank-you Perks when you become a Human Being Positively Human by contributing.


You win, They win, WE ALL WIN!



If we don't reach our goal, the funds will go exactly where they're needed most - to our artists who are producing the documentary film, music,  photography, audio stories, fine art, and the written word.

W H Y do we want to pay our artists?

We believe our culture is defined by the Arts and Humanities. Far too often, artists are "starving", and yet they are creating such a valuable part of what we see and experience as "culture". All of our artists spend countless hours in service to the homeless community, most of them volunteer hours. We want them to be compensated for the great value they add to our project, to our community, and to the world.
They are Humans Being Positively Human and what they offer in each of the media in which they work contributes to growth, healing, and COMMUNITY. 


If we don't reach our goal, we will keep on going, and create additional ways to fund this project.


More crowdfunding, more grant writing, more creative revenue streams!


WE are UNSTOPPABLE Humans Being Positively Human

 

The Impact

We have experienced the vulnerability and fear people have about homelessness and homeless people. It is not easy, for many reasons, to see people living on the streets. It is what inspired our co-creator, Terry Worden, to write a song "You Can See the People", which is the theme song on our video and a download and lyric sheet, one of our Perks.

Many people feel frustrated that such a wealthy planet has people without shelter literally dying on the streets, and others just feel scared a homeless person (or someone they think is homeless) will threaten their safety. 

"A Place to Call Home" fosters greater understanding from the stories "caught" and shared in the various media in which our artists work.  This results in greater connection to the humanity of us all, and translates to less fear. Through capturing and sharing fascinating stories of those involved  and connected with the homeless community, we have already experienced more compassion and generosity by the people listening to the audio segments, viewing photographs and fine art, reading the essays and stories, and listening to the original music created by our artists.

By August, 2017, we will have caught, recorded, and shared 60 audio stories from homeless people, those organizations working with the homeless, concerned citizens, and officials charged with finding solutions. Photographs are being taken, stories and poetry written, artwork and music created. From this wealth of creative multi-media, we are creating the interactive and experiential event in November, using real life situations to communicate and encourage empathy.

Our Supporters, Advocates, Believers, Champions, Enthusiasts, and Angels  - the Humans Being Positively Human - who contribute to our campaign, will know they are part of creating avenues for solutions to the far-reaching and multi-faceted problem of homelessness in our world - and that they are supporting the Arts and Humanities; a real W I N - W I N - W I N.

They will be helping us produce the documentary film, original music CD, and 2018 daily compassionate action calendar - all products developed through the stories we capture. We envision these products being used to shift perceptions and help homelessness here in Nevada County, California,  and to co-create a collaborative movement throughout the world.

What if we knew what to DO to co-create an inclusive world that worked for ALL???

You can be sure that Betty Louise and Susan Davis have experience co-creating with others, as Betty Louise is a certified Co-Active Coach and Leader for almost 20 years, and co-led a course designed at Stanford University on chronic conditions for 15 years. Susan Davis founded The Co-Creation Community, and wrote the curriculum to "9 Steps to Marketing Success", and has facilitated teams for decades. They call themselves the "Co-Pros", because collaboration and bringing community together for the greater good is in their blood and is the path they've walked their entire lives.

 

Risks & Challenges

We know there are many people looking for funds for their valuable special projects. We know that getting people to write checks for social justice issues is easy for some and hard for others. We know that often people don't realize the financial cost to producing meaningful, quality products - especially those relying on the hard work of artists, writers, musicians, filmmakers, and media professionals.

We will address these challenges by providing high quality content that people feel good about supporting, using, and sharing - content they can use in their own daily lives. We will listen to what our contributors are most interested in, and keep them  in the loop of our activities and progress. 

Homelessness is getting a lot of media attention, and the time is ripe for breaking through old thinking to co-create new solutions. Let's find a more effective way to take care of some of our most vulnerable citizens. Let's shift the perceptions that keep us from having the mindset of "They are Us. We are Them. We are One. And we ALL need a place to call HOME"
 

"A society will be judged on the basis of how it treats its weakest members" 

~Pope John Paul II

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We've created a Shout-Out/Outreach & PR page on our website so helping us spread the word about the A-Place-To-Call-Home Project is EASY!
We'd so appreciate frequent and consistent support online, in social media, in blogs, in the press.

  • Help spread the word about our Humans Being Positively Human - A-Place-To-Call-Home Indiegogo Campaign.
  • Like our Facebook Page and share it with ALL your Facebook friends. Check in often and
  • Like, Comment, and Share posts in all Social Media channels
  • Join our eMail List and Share our Website; let your family and friends know about our campaign - MAKE SOME NOISE and Be a Human Being Positively Human
  • Any audio/video editors out there? We could use some help.
  • Know anyone involved with homelessness that would be willing to share their story?
  • Know of any grants or other creative funding ideas that fit our project? Send them on over!

It is what inspired our co-creator, Terry Worden, to write a song "You Can See the People", which is the theme song on our video and a download and lyric sheet, one of our Perks.
Many people feel frustrated that such a wealthy planet has people without shelter literally dying on the streets, and others just feel scared a homeless person (or someone they think is homeless) will threaten their safety. 

"A Place to Call Home" fosters greater understanding from the stories "caught" and shared in the various media in which our artists work.  This results in greater connection to the humanity of us all, and translates to less fear. Through capturing and sharing fascinating stories of those involved  and connected with the homeless community, we have already experienced more compassion and generosity by the people listening to the audio segments, viewing photographs and fine art, reading the essays and stories, and listening to the original music created by our artists.By August, 2017, we will have caught, recorded, and shared 60 audio stories from homeless people, those organizations working with the homeless, concerned citizens, and officials charged with finding solutions. Photographs are being taken, stories and poetry written, artwork and music created. From this wealth of creative multi-media, we are creating the interactive and experiential event in November, using real life situations to communicate and encourage empathy.

Our Supporters, Advocates, Believers, Champions, Enthusiasts, and Angels  - the Humans Being Positively Human - who contribute to our campaign, will know they are part of creating avenues for solutions to the far-reaching and multi-faceted problem of homelessness in our world - and that they are supporting the Arts and Humanities; a real W I N - W I N - W I N.
They will be helping us produce the documentary film, original music CD, and 2018 daily compassionate action calendar - all products developed through the stories we capture. We envision these products being used to shift perceptions and help homelessness here in Nevada County, California,  and to co-create a collaborative movement throughout the world.
What if we knew what to DO to co-create an inclusive world that worked for ALL???
You can be sure that Betty Louise and Susan Davis have experience co-creating with others, as Betty Louise is a certified Co-Active Coach and Leader for almost 20 years, and co-led a course designed at Stanford University on chronic conditions for 15 years. Susan Davis founded The Co-Creation Community, and wrote the curriculum to "9 Steps to Marketing Success", and has facilitated teams for decades. They call themselves the "Co-Pros", because collaboration and bringing community together for the greater good is in their blood and is the path they've walked their entire lives.
 

Risks & Challenges
We know there are many people looking for funds for their valuable special projects. We know that getting people to write checks for social justice issues is easy for some and hard for others. We know that often people don't realize the financial cost to producing meaningful, quality products - especially those relying on the hard work of artists, writers, musicians, filmmakers, and media professionals.
We will address these challenges by providing high quality content that people feel good about supporting, using, and sharing - content they can use in their own daily lives. We will listen to what our contributors are most interested in, and keep them  in the loop of our activities and progress. 
Homelessness is getting a lot of media attention, and the time is ripe for breaking through old thinking to co-create new solutions. Let's find a more effective way to take care of some of our most vulnerable citizens. Let's shift the perceptions that keep us from having the mindset of "They are Us. We are Them. We are One. And we ALL need a place to call HOME"

 
"A society will be judged on the basis of how it treats its weakest members" 
~Pope John Paul II

 


 

Other Ways You Can Help
We've created a Shout-Out/Outreach & PR page on our website so helping us spread the word about the A-Place-To-Call-Home Project is EASY!We'd so appreciate frequent and consistent support online, in social media, in blogs, in the press.


Help spread the word about our Humans Being Positively Human - A-Place-To-Call-Home Indiegogo Campaign.

Like our Facebook Page and share it with ALL your Facebook friends. Check in often and
Like, Comment, and Share posts in all Social Media channels

Join our eMail List and Share our Website; let your family and friends know about our campaign - MAKE SOME NOISE and Be a Human Being Positively Human


Any audio/video editors out there? We could use some help.


Know anyone involved with homelessness that would be willing to share their story?

Know of any grants or other creative funding ideas that fit our project? Send them on over!

story:
A Season Full of DGR Action

Deep Green Resistance is a movement to save the planet and fight injustice, and we are recruiting. We are hitting the road in June all around the world, attending action camps, participating in direct action, touring with educational presentations, and mobilizing the resistance.

Every resistance movement needs two things to be successful: loyalty and material support. To get that material support - food, shelter, transportation - we need YOUR help. Every donation goes directly to funding the resistance. Our work is 100% volunteer run and we are not some corrupt NGO. We are the grassroots and we work with the people for justice.

Will you help us? Every donation gets us closer to making this summer season the biggest in our short history - and moves us closer towards the goal of a flourishing, living world.

Upcoming Actions:

We have a lot coming up, and we need your support to make it all happen. This summer, DGR members will be:

  • Participating in actions against the Keystone XL pipeline
  • Organizing with the Lakota people against liquid genocide in White Clay
  • Fighting the first Tar Sands project in the USA in eastern Utah
  • Hosting regional organizing conferences in Cascadia and the Northeast USA
  • Touring the Northeast US and SE Canada to share the DGR message
  • Working to show solidarity with the Winnemum Wintu Tribe to protect their sacred ceremonies
  • Attending solidarity actions in Detroit, Wisconsin, Minnesota & North Carolina
  • Training the next generation of resistors at a training camp in South Dakota
To make all of this happen, we need money for food, travel costs, lodging, supplies, and more. Help us make our goal and share this campaign with your friends!

The Impact

Our goal is to have a material impact on injustice. We work to fight oppression and end the destruction of Mother Earth. It is our belief that we must do the right thing, we must not compromise, and we must work hard.
 
We are not afraid to go to jail, to put our lives on the line, to fight and bleed and die for liberation. Come stand with us. We need your help!

Other Ways To Help

Some people just can’t contribute monetarily, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread this information as widely as you can
  • Ask friends and family to contribute
  • Join DGR and organize to save the planet and fight injustice

story:
According to International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), hundreds of thousands   of people are now without running water, and within days, the entire Gaza population "will desperately run short of water resources". 

Since the beginning of the Israeli war on Gaza, Israel has continuously targeted vital infrastructure such as Power, Water, Agriculture and Schools. One area to see unprecedented destruction was the Gazan town of Khuza'a. 

In 10 days Israel demolished the entire town - shown here in this 360 shot taken and reported by The Telegraph, and above in a video by Freedom Aid Global Ground Volunteer Walid Rouk & International Human Rights Activist Denny Cormier.

I have decided to put myself to the test by facing my fears and bungee jumping for vital water aid in Khuza'a, Gaza!

As a journalist at Freedom Aid, I have seen from our past projects the way we endeavour to rapidly respond to the needy across the globe, utilising money effectively and tangibly.

My target is £700 only. With this money we can provide 5 x 1500 litre Clean Water Tanks (£115 each and this includes maintenance). That's a whopping 7,500 litres in total, each tank can last upto a month!!

We would most certainly help our loved ones if needed, so why do we choose not to help our fellow human beings; those who share the same blood, skin and bones as we do? 

Please sponsor me to raise money for those in urgent need of water. We are their only hope. Donate Now!

story:
The Social Justice Fund's Gender Justice Giving Project is providing grants to organizations working on critical gender justice issues. We've nearly reached our $80,000 fundraising goal for the 2014 season--help us make it all the way!


What is gender justice anyway?

Gender justice exists when all people -- especially women, girls, and gender-variant people -- are able to identify and express their gender and sexual orientation without fear, discrimination or harm and have the economic, social, and political power and resources to make healthy decisions for themselves, their families and their communities in all areas of their lives.

It will require transformation at interpersonal, institutional, systemic and cultural levels. There are three issue areas at the core of Gender Justice:

  • LGBTQ Justice
  • Reproductive Justice
  • Family Security

(Definition adapted from Western States Center and Forward Together.)


...and the Gender Justice Project?

The Gender Justice Giving Project:

  • is a group of 20 volunteers pooling our money, time, resources, and skills to fund gender justice organizing. 
  • is multi-gendered, queer and straight, multiracial and cross-class, working together. 
  • will make grants to gender justice organizing that is often overlooked by mainstream funders (particularly but not exclusively in communities of color).
A focus on funding work in this particular area is critical.

  • Approximately 1.5% of foundation funding goes to community organizing.
  • About 7% of foundation funding is targeted to communities of color. 
  • About 5.8% is targeted to women and girls (the majority is for health programs).
  • About 0.3% goes to LGBTQ communities (recently, the majority is for marriage campaigns). 
  • Of that... about 11% is targeted to communities of color, 5% to women, and 4% to transgender/gender non-conforming people.
  • The sliver of funding that addresses the overlap of any of these areas is extremely small. That means that every dollar has an even bigger impact!


How does an SJF Giving Project work?

This video by Reel Grrls says it best:


      Awesome. How else can I help?

      • Tell everyone you know about SJF, the Gender Justice Giving Project and our indiegogo campaign.
      • Join the Social Justice Fund! Join a Giving Project! For info on getting more involved, visit the SJF website.

story:
This crowdfunding campaign is now closed. If you're interested in donating please contact alexandra.steinkraus@freedomrefugeesmn.org 

The initiator of the symposium, and the founder of the Freedom For North Korean Refugees of Minnesota organization is Hyon Kim, a Twin Cities entrepreneur whose interest in North Korean refugees comes out of her personal life story. Like many other Korean Americans, Hyon comes from a family that was divided when Korea was divided into north and south after World War II, a condition that was supposed to be temporary but is still in place today.  This diplomatic impasse has permanently separated an estimated 100,000 families. 

 As a four-year-old, she was separated from parents and siblings in 1951, and thereafter was brought up by an aunt in South Korea.  After a youth spent trying to work to support herself and go to high school, she had a career in the South Korean army as an officer,  and in the U.S. Army as a civilian employee.  She immigrated to Minnesota at age 24. 

Since living in Minnesota, in addition to raising two sons as a single mother, she has been an entrepreneur and owner of several businesses. She also been active in the community organizations, and has held numerous high-level leadership positions, including a term as a Regent of the University of Minnesota. 

She has worked as a volunteer with refugees from many countries in local outreach efforts, and would like Minnesota to one day become a welcoming home for North Korean refugees as well.  When Hyon thinks of North Korean refugees, she can see her father, mother, brothers and other ordinary people.  She wants others to also be able to think of these refugees as ordinary people in need of help and a place to live.  The symposium is a first step toward that goal. 

North Korea has one of the most horrifying human rights records in the entire world. 

As estimated 200,000 defectors have escaped the poverty and oppression of their government, hoping to reach safety in South Korea. To do so, these stateless people must undertake hazardous treks through China and other countries. 

Many never make it across miles of Gobi Dessert, mountains, and similarly treacherous terrain for even a chance at diplomatic immunity. 

Women and children make up to an estimated 70 percent of North Koreans seeking exile. All are vulnerable to opportunists, most - maybe all the females among them - are forced into human trafficking, slavery, and other crimes. If caught by Chinese authorities, these refugees have no claim to diplomatic asylum. They are deported immediately to North Korea, where they often face torture or imprisonment.   

Despite all this, the world community has done little to provide these refugees resettlement. 

Freedom for North Korean refugees of Minnesota wants to change that. 

On October 19th, 2015 Freedom for North Korean refugees of Minnesota will be hosting a symposium that spreads awareness and understanding of the human rights issues of North Korean refugees and spark an effort to establish long overdue solutions. 

A number of North Korean refugees are among the remarkable group of Koreans who have agreed to come and share their stories! Additionally, subject matter experts from academic, human rights, diplomacy, media social services, faith organizations, and the arts will join them to inform us on the facts and current status of this complex international issue. Together they will illuminate the realities of refugees' lives in China, giving us a vivid glimpse into the desperation people face when they have no country and no legal rights. 

Most immediately, we are in need of funds to support the development, promotion and launch of this much-needed program and to secure and support the costs of expert presenters and speakers. With your help, we can engage community partners in a dialogue that will go beyond this symposium and transform into meaningful outcomes in our communities.  The result will be a way to provide desperately-needed support and aid for safe and humane resettlement of North Korean refugees in Minnesota and elsewhere in the U.S.

In the video above, Yeon-Mi Park, a North Korean defector and human rights activist tells her story about escaping from North Korea in 2007 and experience on the popular South Korean show On My Way To Meet You. Once a member of the elite in Pyongyang, once her father was arrested for illegal trading, her family had to flee. Yeon-Mi first saw The Titanic in 1997, and got her first glimpse into the outside world. Later, Yeon-Mi would see a family friend executed for selling DVDs, making her realize how oppressive and horrific the North Korean government truly was. Once in China, Yeon-Mi was vulnerable to trafficking, and even saw her own mother raped in front of her. Please help others like Yeon-Mi by donating and helping us save women and children from sex trafficking and abuse. With you help we can make a difference.
story_txt:
This crowdfunding campaign is now closed. If you're interested in donating please contact alexandra.steinkraus@freedomrefugeesmn.org

story:
Who are we?

  • We are four undergraduate students at the University of Tennessee Knoxville who saw a need in Knoxville and wanted to make an impact. 
  • We have all seen first-hand the impact of domestic violence and know how important it is for women to have resources and a safe place to find sanctuary. 
  • Any contribution will be used at its max to give the YWCA  more resources.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break'n it Down

  • Our funds for this campaign with are being directed towards the Keys of Hope transitional program at the YWCA Knoxville & the Tennessee Valley. This program takes in at-risk women and helps them get on their feet again. They emphasize helping these women reach their goals and their end game is helping them become independent.
  • Donations will provide these residents with items that many of us take for granted such as bedding, hygiene, products or food. 
  • When you donate you won't only get a friendship bracelet but a chance to win a gift basket filled win snacks, candles, bath bombs, facemasks, and many more things every girl wants!

The Impact

  • Every single dollar and donation will help the YWCA further help the women in the Knoxville area.  
  • The YWCA Knoxville & the Tennessee Valley is a longstanding organization, founded in 1899, and has a great history of making a difference. 

Risks & Challenges

  • Obviously, this campaign is focused towards women, but that doesn't mean you can't support if you are a male. Just think about all the impactful women in your life, and all the other helpless women who have no place to go that you can help with just the click of a few buttons.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? You can still help!

  • A share, a retweet, or a post is just as beneficial to our campaign! Awareness of domestic violence and the YWCA is just as significant as the campaign.  
  • Make an impact. If you see a woman in need, get her help or show her that there are an abundance of resources available 

And that's all there is to it.

Facebook hashtag #OperationExposeCPD

http://youtu.be/I9rQSmJz8nw

What We Need & What You Get

I want to produce a quality documentary with whistle blower and need a staff.  As you can see in background I am good on equipment.  I went to school for production.  But I do need a staff.  The documentary will be posted on Social Media for all to see for free.. This will change politics and police in Chicago forever. 

http://youtu.be/I9rQSmJz8nw

We need help as far as marketing, and just getting this out there.  We are fighting powerful corruption and finally have an insider whistle blower.

The Impact

It's a whistle blower, four decades on force.  Has pictures with him and drunk Mayor Daley.  We expose so much that many cases will have to be retried.  Many people might be set free, and at the very least at least the information will be out and they can't do this any more.  Police corruption stops when the population stands up united. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Marketing, social media, production staff.  Legal, and any thing else you can contribute is appreciated.
