story:
Under One Sky was founded on the principle that humanity is ONE family…we are brothers and sisters regardless of nationality, race, religion, class or any other label. Our mission is to lift the spirits of those living without a home and make them feel loved.

“Your spirit is the true shield” Morihei Ueshiba

For the 4th year running Under One Sky is reaching out to those in London who have to survive the winter without place to call home. But this year we are also expanding our efforts to include refugees in the Calais Jungle camp.

In the previous 3 years more than 100 fantastic volunteers have provided support to 500 homeless from £15,000 in donations. One night close to Christmas we hand out gift cards, clothing, meals and messages of hope and light to the homeless. The gift cards can be used to buy sleeping bags, winter clothing or other life necessities.  

Once again homeless numbers are up in London and several thousand refugees are stranded in Calais. The need is bigger than ever.

Your funds will go to:

  1. Gift cards to shops that sell basic necessities such as sleeping bags and winter clothing. These will be handed out on at our Night for the Homeless event in London as we have done in previous years.
  2. Gear for surviving in the Calais refugee camp such as sleeping bags, winter clothing, tents, torches, dictionaries and more. We will drive these supplies to Calais and distribute in camp. We are working with the organisation Caravans for Calais who have people on the ground in the camp.

If you are not in a position to donate then we’d love a message of hope and light from you or a share, tweet…any shout-out. If you wish to send a message for the homeless/refugees then please use the comments section to leave your message including first name and city / country.

We can't wait to bring your donations to those fighting to survive on the streets of London and in the refugee camp in Calais!  

One love from the Under One Sky team

https://www.facebook.com/Under1Sky

 

Out of respect for those homeless souls we met at our previous events we are not sharing pictures of previous events on this page. We do not know where they are in their lives today but sincerely hope at least some have a roof over their heads now.

However below you can read about one success story of an encounter turning into a friendship and see pictures of the conditions in the jungle refugee camp in Calais.

From homeless to hopeful for the future

In February 2014 we met Miguel in a dark alley close to St James tube station. He was full of spirit and emotional stories. We had a long chat with him as he told us his journey of how he ended up on the streets. We shared our contact details with him and fortunately he got back in touch. Since then we have been in regular contact with Miguel and that grew into a friendship. Thankfully Miguel now has a roof over his head and is focussing on rebuilding his life.  

First meeting with Miguel

 

Lunch with Miguel at British Museum

 

The reality of living in The Jungle refugee camp in Calais

Around 7000 refugees live in The Jungle tent camp. This is not an officially recognised camp and therefore major aid agencies do not have free reign to offer help.  A few of the Under One Sky team have spent time in the camp and our pictures below give you an idea of the terrible living conditions. Now imagine what life will be like when winter comes.
story_txt:
Under One Sky was founded on the principle that humanity is ONE family…we are brothers and sisters regardless of nationality, race, religion, class or any other label. Our mission is to lift the spirits of those living without a home and make them feel loved.“Your spirit is the true shield” Morihei UeshibaFor the 4th year running Under One Sky is reaching out to those in London who have to survive the winter without place to call home. But this year we are also expanding our efforts to include refugees in the Calais Jungle camp.In the previous 3 years more than 100 fantastic volunteers have provided support to 500 homeless from £15,000 in donations. One night close to Christmas we hand out gift cards, clothing, meals and messages of hope and light to the homeless. The gift cards can be used to buy sleeping bags, winter clothing or other life necessities.  Once again homeless numbers are up in London and several thousand refugees are stranded in Calais. The need is bigger than ever.Your funds will go to:
Gift cards to shops that sell basic necessities such as sleeping bags and winter clothing. These will be handed out on at our Night for the Homeless event in London as we have done in previous years.
Gear for surviving in the Calais refugee camp such as sleeping bags, winter clothing, tents, torches, dictionaries and more. We will drive these supplies to Calais and distribute in camp. We are working with the organisation Caravans for Calais who have people on the ground in the camp.
If you are not in a position to donate then we’d love a message of hope and light from you or a share, tweet…any shout-out. If you wish to send a message for the homeless/refugees then please use the comments section to leave your message including first name and city / country.We can't wait to bring your donations to those fighting to survive on the streets of London and in the refugee camp in Calais!  One love from the Under One Sky teamhttps://www.facebook.com/Under1Sky Out of respect for those homeless souls we met at our previous events we are not sharing pictures of previous events on this page. He was full of spirit and emotional stories. We had a long chat with him as he told us his journey of how he ended up on the streets. We shared our contact details with him and fortunately he got back in touch. Since then we have been in regular contact with Miguel and that grew into a friendship. Thankfully Miguel now has a roof over his head and is focussing on rebuilding his life.  First meeting with Miguel Lunch with Miguel at British Museum The reality of living in The Jungle refugee camp in CalaisAround 7000 refugees live in The Jungle tent camp. This is not an officially recognised camp and therefore major aid agencies do not have free reign to offer help.  A few of the Under One Sky team have spent time in the camp and our pictures below give you an idea of the terrible living conditions. Now imagine what life will be like when winter comes.

story:
So, we made our minimum goal of $2,500...what now? 

We will now be able to install 100% of the system!  But, we always knew we could exceed our goal!  Now that we have, all additional funds will be used to improve the hanging displays with new frames for some of the pictures and new materials for the displays.  Nothing will go to waste and 100% of all the funds we receive will go to improving the wall displays.  We can use an additional $1,000 or more toward these materials.  Let's see how close we can get to $3,500, $4,000, $5,000 . . . it's all up to you!

Who We Are

We are a small organization and not part of the City of Portland.  We rely entirely on contributions to keep our doors open (free admission) and to maintain our collection of artifacts, photographs and memorabilia that dates back to the 1850's and early law enforcement in Oregon.

The Portland Police Museum is located at 1111 SW 2nd Avenue in the first floor of the Central Police Precinct.  Admission is FREE and we are open 10am to 3pm - Tuesdays through Fridays.  The Museum is one of three parts to the Portland Police Historical Society (P.P.H.S.).   P.P.H.S. is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization and your contribution in tax deductible as allowed by law.

Without your help, and the contributions of many others, none of this would be possible.

What We Need & What You Get

The walls of the museum are covered with great old photos, posters, and information about the exhibits.  But, they are either stuck on with sticky tape or hanging from things stuck in the wall.  The stuck on things sometimes fall and the holes need to be patched and painted to change any displays. 

AND, honestly...it just does not look as good as it could.  Together, we can do much better.

By joining us in this campaign you will make it possible to install up to 144 feet of the STAS picture hanging system on all the walls in the museum.  Pictures will hang perfectly placed and new displays will go up without a hitch.  

AND, things will just look and function a whole lot better.

*PERKS?  Yes, we have those for you too!  Perks range from our unwavering gratitude, to patches, to miniature badge charms, to replica badges and having your name placed on a section of the newly installed wall track for the STAS system.  

*All perks will be sent in December 2014.  If you choose the $100 "Sponsor a Yard Plus Perk" we will contact you about what name you want on your nameplate to be certain we get it right!

With your help we will reach our goal!
But, if we don't we will still receive funds from whatever you pledge.  We will install as much of the system as is funded.  $2,500 and we install 100%, $1,250 and we install 50%.   But, we can and hope to exceed our goal!  If we do, then all additional funds will be used to improve the hanging displays with new frames for some of the pictures and new materials for the displays.  Nothing will go to waste and 100% of all the funds we receive will go to improving the wall displays.

The Impact

We are working hard to improve the quality and appearance of the displays.  This system is the first big step.  Once this is done...it will last and be used for decades.  Your contribution will have a long lasting impact on thousands of visitors for the years to come. 

  • We are a small non-profit and $2,500 may be a small amount to others but it is big to us!
  • This type of system is used by many museums and galleries throughout the world.
  • This is a one time cost.  Whether you donate $5 or $100, it will have a big lasting impact.

Risks & Challenges

There really are no risks.  We will continue to be open (for free) and host visitors throughout the year.  Please do what you can...every contribution gets us closer to our goal of a minimum of $2,500. 

  • If we go over...every extra dollar will be used to improve the objects displayed on the walls with new frames, reproductions and display holders - no funds will be used for any other purpose.

Help Us Spread The Word!

Help us spread the word!

  • Please share this with your friends!
  • Encourage others to donate too!

If we go over...every extra dollar will be used to improve the objects displayed on the walls with new frames, reproductions and display holders - no funds will be used for any other purpose. 
  Help Us Spread The Word! Help us spread the word!

Please share this with your friends!
Encourage others to donate too!

story:
We, the members of Abemi, are residents of Gugulethu, a historically black township in the urban periphery of Cape Town, South Africa.  Under apartheid, the Group Areas Act (1950) legalized segregation and designated the best land in the city as "white".  As a result, thousands were forcibly relocated to townships on the outskirts of the city, including Gugulethu, which was established in 1958.  Today, over 98,000 people call Gugulethu home, including many who live in backyard shacks and informal settlements.  Together we have formed a grassroots human rights organization to advocate for the poorest of the poor in our community.  

We believe in the power of our community to come together, make our brothers' and sisters' problems OUR problems, and solve them together.  Although we have won our freedom in South Africa, not everyone has benefitted and many suffer from basic human rights violations, including the right to: affordable, dignified housing; education; sanitation; and food.

The struggle continues.  Many of the oppressive conditions created by apartheid persist today, especially in the townships.  Abemi works to close the gap and serve the most vulnerable in our community: the elderly, the disabled, women, children, and the poor.  

However, to do this, we need to establish a dedicated office space where we can meet community members, consult on the challenges they are facing, and work to advocate for them.  We hope to purchase a used shipping container to convert into an office.  In total, we estimate that the container, the cost of transporting the container, and some second-hand office furniture (desks, chairs, a filing cabinet, and a phone line) will cost $3,000.  Although it will be modest, having an office space will give us a platform that will empower us to fight for justice in our community.  

Gugulethu means "our pride" in Xhosa, our language.  Please, help us restore the dignity and pride of our people!  

Abemi is a registered nonprofit organization with the South African Department of Social Development.

story:
One year ago, on the 1st of April 2018 a group of people living in a refugee camp in northern Greece, Katsikas, and some team members from the organization Soup and Socks embarked on an adventure of running a half-marathon to raise awareness about the situation of refugees in Greece and for people’s FREEDOM OF MOVEMENT. One year later the situation for the people living in Camp Katsikas remains unchanged. Now, the camp accommodates 993 people from different parts of the world who are in a stagnant situation. Together with some of the runners who participated last year and some new runners we want to participate in the full MARATHON in Olympia to let people know we are still running – that the situation of refugees in Greece is unchanged and that the basic human right of freedom of movement is still being violated.

This year, we want to raise €3.500 to enable people from Camp Katsikas and Habibi.Works to run a full marathon on the 31st of March 2019. The money raised will cover the entire costs for participating in the run; registration fees, running gear such as shoes, shirts and shorts, transportation from and to the race, accommodation, and food.

Every cent that will be raised on top of the costs for the run, will go directly into realizing people’s projects in our maker space Habibi.Works. Powered by the German NGO Soup and Socks e.V., Habibi.Works is an intercultural maker space, which provides platforms for education, empowerment and encounter. In eleven different working areas, people from nearby refugee camps and locals have the possibility to get active, create, take first steps of integration and share knowledge. 

In case we do not manage to fundraise the target amount, the costs will be covered for as many people as can join with the fundraised money. Help us make sure all the 15 highly motivated and enthusiastic runners can participate!

We will be running the Olympia Marathon in the historic ancient city of Olympia. For all the supporters who want to encourage the runners during the race, we will cheer together at the finish line in Ancient Olypmia.

Support the runners in their quest to run for their right to movement at the Olympia Marathon.

The Impact

Enabling people whose lives have been put on hold to participate in sports activities will benefit the participants in a number of ways:

  • General mental and physical health benefit of sports;
  • Community building through training, preparation and participating together despite nationality, gender, ethnicity and age;
  • Working towards a goal and an achievement in a context where lives have been put on hold and people are continuously waiting;
  • Giving people a stage to raise awareness about the ongoing challenges asylum seekers face in Greece;
  • Amplify the supporting network of Habibi.Works to ensure the sustainable development of the services we are offering to empower people.

Meet the Runners:

Ali

Ali Ahmad is from Afghanistan and he is 25 years old. Ali has been in Greece for one year and five months, of which he lived one year and two months on Lesvos, and three months in Katsikas. Before Ali came to Greece he was in the army in Afghanistan. When it got too dangerous for him to stay he left to Greece.

“I have been running my whole live, in Afghanistan, in Lesvos and now here in Katsikas. It is very important for me to run, for both body and mind. Without running I would only sit in my container, which would create problems for my mind”.

Mamadou

Mamadou is from Guinea. He is 19 years old. He came to Greece in January 2018 and was moved to Katsikas in October 2018. He worked in a supermarket, a family business, before leaving from Guinea.

“I love to run because it is my dream to become a professional football player. In Guinea there are no events like this and I want to participate in the marathon to make my country proud and be proud of my nationality. If I do sport it diminishes my stress and enforces my physical strength”.

Abdoullah

Abdoullah is 21 years old and is from Guinea. In Guinea Abdoullah played football professionally for fc loubah (before in the 1st division and now in the second division). On the 26th of December, just over year ago, Abdoullah came to Greece. He spent 9 months in Lesvos camp before coming to Katsikas Camp.

"Sport is good. When I have some problems and I go and do sport it makes me feel good. It is a good training and I feel good running. In all my life I do sport and when I do this I feel good. When I do sport I forget the situation on the island and the situation in the camp.I want to continue my football in Europe this is my job and my passion."

Ahmad

Ahmed is from Syria. He is 22 years old. He has been in Greece for 1.5 years, of which he spent six months in Samos and more than one year in Katsikas. In Syria he worked in his own supermarket. Ahmed also ran the first half marathon we did one year ago.

“I love all sports. It is important for my body, and a healthy body is important for a good life. This year I want to participate in the marathon because after every race I run, I am encouraged to go one step further. We ran half a marathon last year, and 30 kilometers in September. Now I want to run a full marathon. I still want to be the first one. I am encouraged to train every day because we run together. By joining in the marathon I feel more integrated in Europe, because there are people from all over Europe. This is very important for me”.

Mohammad

Mohammad is 20 years old and comes from Baghdad in Iraq. In Baghdad he played football and his dream is to become a professional football player. Two years ago he left Iraq and came to Greece. He was on Lesvos in Mouria camp for one year and a half living in a tent before coming to Katsikas in October 2018.

“I want to be fit for football. My dream is to become a professional football player with Liverpool. For me sport is very important. Here the people only eat and sleep. It is so boring. For me playing sport is a way to tire my mind and body”.

Jagana

Mohammad aka Jagana is 21 years old and comes from Senegal. Jagana grew up with sports playing an important part in his life. Him and his family cultivated a piece of land. He came to Greece on the 6th of November 2017. He spent nine months on Lesvos, a lot of the time he was in Mouria. In September 2018 he was moved to Katsikas and has been actively playing football ever since.

“Sport is important for my health and I like all kinds of sports. If I don’t do sports I will not feel good. I met a bunch of guys during a Gambia versus Guinea game in Lesvos. After coming to Katikas the people that I met in Lesvos and I started training together. Running is very important for a football player to stay fit and in shape”.

Henry

Henry is from Nigeria. In May he will turn 22 years old. In Nigeria Henry was playing football professionally. In 2016 he left Nigeria and went to Istanbul, Turkey. There he also found a team to play football. After a year in Turkey, Henry came to Greece in 2017 and has been living in Mouria camp for eleven months before coming to Katsikas. Now he plays football here with some of the people he met in Mouria.

“Sport gives me joy and happiness. I want to use sport to achieve my goals, sport is my dream. I love to play football. It gives me joy to play in a team. I want to run the marathon because I want to be fit and challenge my body”.

Ghazem

Ghazem is from Afghanistan, Mazarshrif. He is 32 years old. Before coming to Greece, he worked as a welder. He left Afghanistan in 2004 to Iran. In August 2017 he left Iran and has been in Greece since then. In April last year he ran the half-marathon in Olympia and also participated in the 30km Lake Run in Ioannina.

"I run for my health. I just want to be healthy. Also, we need to spread the word that people are still living in camps, their lives put on hold and they are just waiting until decisions are made for them"

Baraa

Baraa is from Burkina Faso, Ouagadougou. He has been in Greece for one year and three months, of which 1 year on Lesvos, and 3 months in Katsikas. In Burkina Faso he worked as a tailor, he liked his job a lot and is still sewing a lot in Habibi.Works.

“I played a lot of sports in Burkina Faso. I played football and I ran a lot. Now I want to put my skills in use again and join in the marathon. Running is important for me because it makes me feel good, both physically and mentally”.

Elske

Elske is from the Netherlands, the Hague. She is 27 years old. She has been working in Habibi.Works since she came to Greece on a bicycle in June 2017. She has been organizing and setting up a running group with people living in the camp. Successfully they have participated in the half-marathon, a 10km race in Ioannina and the 30km Lake Run in Ioannina.

"I want to run because it is a great way to relax my mind and interact with our amazing neighbors from camp Katsikas. It is a great way to bond with people and strive for a common goal. Furthermore, I think it is very important that the situation of refugees here in Greece is addressed. People in Europe seem to have forgotten about them, but at the same time they are still here, stuck in Greece without any freedom of movement."

Kiki

Kiki is from Germany, Berlin. She is 27 years old. She is working in Habibi.Works and has been in Greece since February 2017. Together with Elske, she has set up a running group that runs together most mornings. Until now they have participated in three races with the biggest one, the marathon, yet to come.

"I want to run to raise awareness for peoples' situation in Greece and stand in solidarity with people who are stuck here against their will. Moreover, running helps me to stay fit, is an outlet to keep me balanced and is a great team building experience"   

Ahmad

Ahmad is Kurdish and is from Syria from Afrin. He went to school in Aleppo and was able to finish the 9th grade until the war started. He then went to Afrin and stayed there until him and his family came to Greece on the 16th of March 2018. Ahmad was on the island of Samson for seven months before coming to Katsikas.

“I like football and with participating in the marathon I want to try something new. Sport and running is important because it is useful for the health and for the body”.

Nabil

Nabil is from Syria, Afrin. He has been in Greece for 11 months. He stayed on Samos for 7 months, and has been in Katsikas for 4 months. Nabil used to exercise a lot in Syria, mainly fitness.

“I like to run because it makes me fit and it makes my body looks good. I like to run the marathon because I want to challenge myself, and see if I am able to do it. I don’t have any work here, and if you do not work and you don’t do sport, you become lazy. I don’t want this. It is also nice to do sports together, that is what I like about this running group.”

Morteza

Morteza is from Afghanistan, Daikondi, but grew up in Iran. He is 21 years old. Before he left Iran, he graduated from High School. He left Iran in October 2017 and has been in Greece since then. Last year just before the half-marathon he injured his leg and could not join. This year he is attempting the full marathon.

"Running benefits my health and my aim is to win the race. In the past I was the champion in badminton in Turkey. Here, I want to continue sport. I want to run for my freedom of movement because everyone should have the right to move freely".

Qaisar

Qaisar is from Iraq. He is 34 years old. He has been in Greece for 1,5 years. He lived on Samos for 5 months and has been in Katsikas for 1 year. In Iraq Qaiser worked as a truckdriver and car mechanic, he loved his job.

“When I was younger I ran every day after work. Now I run every day around Katsikas. It is good for my mental well being and better then sleeping the whole day. Because of the running I have to wake up in the morning, which is good. Joining in the marathon gives me a goal to work towards to, and it is beautiful to do something together.”

Hussein

Husseini is from Afghanistan, Samangana. He is 24 years old. He grew up in Iran and came to Greece October 2017. He was one of the runners who participated in the half-marathon of Olympia in April 2018, as well as the 30km Lake Run in Ioannina.

"I like exercising and running. It is good for my health. I am stuck in Greece and moved around from camp to camp. None of that is my choice. Participating in the run is my choice. I am choosing to run"

Mukhtar

Mukhtar is from Afghanistan, he is 24 years old. He has been in Greece for 1 year and 8 months. He first stayed in Lesvos for 7 months, and has been in Katsikas for 1 year and 1 month.

“Running is important for the health and it is also fun. If you wake up and run in the morning, you will be fresh the whole day. I want to participate in the marathon because we do this as a group, which is something I like.”

Samad

Samad is from Afghanistan, Maydan Wardak. He is 25 years old. In Afghanistan he was a commandor in the army. He left Afghanistan in October 2017 and has been in Greece since then. Samad participated in the half-marathon last year and has been part of the running group since then.

"I like to run and be healthy. It is good for my body. I will run to open peoples eyes to the fact that the 'crisis' is far from over. We are still stuck in Greece with very little hope to go anywhere else"

Other Ways You Can Help

Although the situation of refugees in Greece is not covered by the media anymore, people are still arriving to Greece everyday, fleeing war and injustice, trying to find a safe place to live their lives. Others have been stuck in Greece for years. It is important to remind everyone that the situation of refugees in Greece has not improved.

For more information concerning our working space and the creative things that happen here take a look:

https://www.facebook.com/HabibiWorks/

https://habibi.works/

 

Stay tuned for updates on the runners and the training...

Yo seriously. #whosbansisthis ???

WHAT IS THIS

Expression through art.

Can't believe what's happening to our country right now? We can't either. Take a stand with us. ALL proceeds go to the ACLU, so our country can shine with diversity like it's supposed to.

WHAT WE NEED

To be heard.

We're not in this for any personal gain. All we're looking for is to let our message carry across, and to band people together in support of equality and non-discrimination.

WHAT YOU GET

Fresh, powerful gear.

You give us money, we give the money to the ACLU to combat discrimination, AND we give you a fresh tee, some stickers, and the peace of mind knowing you're standing for a just cause. Pretty cool, right?

WHY SUPPORT

Because you love humanity.

Be a part of the movement, stand with the oppressed. Help our country shine on its true ideals of human rights for all, regardless of background, race, or religion.

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

This isn't our first runaround.

We are a team experienced in the indie art/apparel business. We've been running Musafir Clothing Co. for about a year now, and you can rest assured we aim to deliver. Not just top notch quality, but pieces designed to start conversation, make a statement, celebrate culture, and tell a story.

The risks we run:

1) Not raising enough to launch this project. But we know you won't let us down, and we're hopeful that you'll carry our message with as much passion as we do.
2) Allowing hatred to overcome peace. The inspiration behind this work is to combat acts of discrimination and oppression by expressing diversity and justice through art. We know that's a message you can get behind.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word.

Post us on your social media, send your friends and loved ones the link to our page, buy extras as gifts, tag your peeps on our page, and love thy neighbor. Our handle on social media is @whosbansisthis. You can connect with us there, we'll make sure to connect back! And make sure to use the hashtag #whosbansisthis in your posts!

WHO MADE THIS?

The dopest artist you'll ever know.

Sarah Noor Rahman is a Pakistani Muslim American artist. She's the visual head at Musafir Clothing Co., and is a freelance artist, helping people with their aesthetic needs. Whether it is paint, graphic design, henna art, photography, fashion design, or editing, Sarah has proven that a head scarf does not hinder creative mastery.

"I'm as Muslim as I am American, and no one can tell me otherwise. I designed this piece because I want America to represent what it did when my parents came here. To stand for opportunity, to stand for equality, and to stand for liberty and justice for all."

story: We all need somebody to lean on...
story_txt: We all need somebody to lean on...

story:
What our film is about

Logline: For the first time, gay couples in Romania sue for the legal right to marry. Filmmaker Anelise Salan is among them and she films her personal and the political journey.Will  she be able to achieve her dream?

Click on the video above to meet me and also watch a trailer from the documentary!

Synopsis: “Forbidden”is a documentary that shows gay couple life for the first time in Romania where being gay is still considered a sin or a perversion by most people. These same sex couples were the first to ever register a same sex marriage request at the local authorities, which the clerk did not approve. Now the case has gone all the way to the European Court of Human Rights while these couples wait for an answer about their future.

Filmmaker Anelise Salan is one of the couples. She started filming for "Forbidden" in early 2018 to document this historic moment for Romania and Southeastern Europe: suing Romania at the European Court of Human Rights for not having a law that protects gay families and allow same sex partnership or marriage.

As part of the film, Anelise also reveals her sexual orientation to the public, and in front of the camera,  and openly talks with her parents for the first time about who she is. She has their support so far but she wants to know how her parents really feel inside and how this public coming out will affect them. They will find out about her marriage plans in front of the camera. Same goes for Anelise' sister, who might have a different reaction because she is a very religious person.

So far, the whole team has worked AS VOLUNTEERS, and after the Coronavirus lockdown, our financial situation dropped to almost zero. We need your help to finish this movie and tell the world this very important story for human rights. It's a story about love and understanding, and we want to show that gay people are just citizens like all the rest but without a basic rights: starting a legal family is our dream and goal!

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping you will be willing to help us finish our film! We are looking for some funds to help finish production and post - production.

Right now we need 1000 euro for the whole team to travel to Anelise's hometown for filming with her family. And 1000 euro for mixing and sound design. This money will only cover the rent for the sound studio, because the sound engineering will work as a volunteer.

Please take a look at the rewards on the right side for your contributions. You could get your name in the credits or a digital copy of the film to watch.

And some exciting news! This film recently won the "Best Discovery" award from the Balkan Documentary Center and now has the support of the state Institute for Culture in Bulgaria.We are so honoured.

 

The Impact

In many western countries or the US, LGBT topic is not an issue anymore. But I think this story is important to remind all of us that those rights are often taken for granted. What if, for some reason some of the basic rights would disappear over night? What if you couldn't marry the person you loved?

To the aggressive resistance of the authorities, I won't reply with a conflict. I have never been in conflict with myself about who I am so why would I be with anyone else? Not even with the State that organized e Referendum against gay families in 2018. I want to show a film about love and couple life that might bring understanding and empathy to the Romanian society and politicians.

I know many teenagers had inner conflicts when they found out they are gay. And maybe a film about a 40 year old gay woman for which things were easy in life, might bring them some comfort.

She came out to her parents, to her teachers at school to her boss. She wasn't kicked out from home or school, she didn't lose her job, etc.

Parents with gay children might feel a bit relieved watching in this film my parents talking about their gay daughter with love and support.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Feel free to share it to the people you know. More people know this story, the better. Either by sharing this campaign on your social media or by emailing to people you know. The more people know this story, the better.

If you have any questions, you can write me directly at forbiddendocumentary@gmail.com

Thank you again for your support!

story:
Short Summary

  • I am Carrie Miller. I have a team of 5 who are leading the way in MI with Our Home Transitional; offering transitional housing for female vets coming back from these wars needing a place to live while transitioning to self-sufficiency. Our program will offer all the governmental and social organizational help needed for this endeavor

  • Our Home Transitional brings these women home again through the offering of transitional housing in a family setting. We do what we are doing because we believe in our purpose, in this dream. We want to provide a trusting home environment for our female vets who have served us and ended up homeless or in distress; without the basic things you and I have like food, clothing, and shelter.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • As a non-profit filing for our 501c3 status through our lawyer, what we need is 1.5 million dollars, 10-20% of which will cover admin, overhead and start-up costs along with salaries and other expenditures. 
  • Once our vet’s transition, Federal monies pour into MI.  For example, employees who hire them will get tax breaks and other incentives; schools that admit them receive $6000 per vet.  Not to mention, a self-sufficient person, vet or otherwise, spends money, investing in our economy – this is your ROI. 

The Impact

 

  • There’s a woman, we’ll call her Mary. Mary has done 2 tours in Afghanistan.  When she comes back, there’s no welcome home, no community to turn to and now she’s ended up on the streets - alone, with no place to go. Just take a few minutes to imagine our women heroes – female veterans - coming home from war to nothing. Our backs turned to them. These women having no place to go, no place to live! 

  • This is also an opportunity to revitalize and beautify the City of Flint as we plan on purchasing several abandoned or foreclosed homes with the funding in a one or 2 block area and even a couple rural ones as well. So I ask you; are you ready to jump on board? Are you ready to help us help those who have served our county? 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join our page and share! It takes a village! https://www.facebook.com/OurHomeTransitional
  • And dont forget to use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
UPDATE: You can select any of the shirts for the $25 Perk!!!

 

From its origins in Southern California, combining a little British heritage with modern design and philanthropy Justice 55 was born. Although still in its infancy, Justice 55's brand plans to become synonymous with wearable clothing that melds classic tailoring with an edgy yet understated aesthetic. Inspired by a desire to create quality constructed clothes, with a passion to give back, they aligned themselves with supremely skilled, local manufacturers in California. The importance of quality, expert craftsmanship and attention to detail resonated deeply, informing Justice 55's core philosophy. With a downtown sensibility and an inherent integrity – each piece is crafted from the finest materials available and approached from a form and function design standpoint – Justice 55 continuously strives for perfection, not only in its products but also with its customer service.

 

We will contact you for sizing and shirt choices at the end of the campaign.

 

100% Organic T Shirts Made in the USA

Compromise is not a dirty word in the U.S.A. Printed with eco-friendly, water-based inks for an extra soft finish. Made in California from 100% organic cotton. Our t-shirts are pajama soft and cut for a classic fit. Women's Scoop neck and Mens Crew neck. Side seamed. Tagless. Preshrunk. Elegant yet comfy. Guaranteed satisfaction.

 

Justice 55 will support National Programs such as Child Help, No Kid Hungry, Generation Rescue and all local community organizations such as The Orange County Child Abuse Prevention Center, South County Outreach and TAALK. We will evaluate all and every organization to be sure they meet our standards!

Justice 55 Donates 20% of all Gross Sales to Children Related Causes.

You are probably asking why would we do this? Well this is why!

 

The funds raised will be used to add incresed inventory and launch a couple of new lines including a denim line.

Our first year goal is to raise $390,000 from our sales to support these causes and support them locally in your back yard.

This could feed 78,000 hungry children in the US for a week or 1500 children for an entire year. It keeps phone lines open to those supporting abused children giving them someone they can talk to in confidence. It supports the early diagnosis and intervention of autism.

By 2018 our goal is to raise $9 million annually for these causes and we need your help to get there!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

 

Limited Edition T Shirt

Our Limited Edition Justice 4 Humanity T shirt is printed with eco-friendly, water-based inks for an extra soft finish. Made in California from 100% organic cotton. Our t-shirts are pajama soft and cut for a classic fit.

 

Say No To Child Abuse T Shirt

Our Say No To Child Abuse T shirt is a simple bold statement for those bold enough to drive the message home. It is printed with eco-friendly, water-based inks for an extra soft finish. Made in California from 100% organic cotton. Our t-shirts are pajama soft and cut for a classic fit.

 

Changing Lives Is How I Roll T Shirt

Our Changing Lives is How I Roll T shirt was designed with a bold statement in mind to draw attention. It is printed with eco-friendly, water-based inks for an extra soft finish. Made in California from 100% organic cotton. Our t-shirts are pajama soft and cut for a classic fit.

 

I'm Aumazing T Shirt

Our I'm Aumazing T shirt was provoked by the dramatic increase in diagnosis of this disorder. These will be available in Children's shirts by Spring. It is printed with eco-friendly, water-based inks for an extra soft finish. Made in California from 100% organic cotton. Our t-shirts are pajama soft and cut for a classic fit.

 

Be The Change T Shirt

Our Be The Change T shirt inspired by Gandhi and is printed with eco-friendly, water-based inks for an extra soft finish. Made in California from 100% organic cotton. Our t-shirts are pajama soft and cut for a classic fit.

Justice 55 Distressed Vintage Baseball Cap

With its distressed, enzyme washed finish and soft feel, this cap already looks like a well-loved favorite.

  • Fabric: 100% cotton twill
  • Structure: Unstructured
  • Profile: Low
  • Closure: Metal D-ring slider buckle with hide-away strap

story:
EGAM is sending a delegation of European Human Rights leaders to Kiev. 

This delegation will gather the main Human Rights defenders from France, Italy, Croatia, Turkey, Czech republic, Greece, Poland, Serbia and more

The delegation will help by : 

  • Supporting the citizens, NGOs, activists on Maidan who need support from other Europeans
  • Protecting the citizens, NGOs, activists on Maidan who are less harrassed when foreigners are around
  • Connecting the citizens, NGOs, activists on Maidan to other Europeans on the long run and thus Building bridges between European and Ukrainian civil societies.
  • Reporting on the situation by writing and spreading a Report on the many Human Rights violations in Kiev to the main European media and institutions
  • Lobbying political leaders in Europe to put pressure on Ukrainian and Russian authorities

Your donation is the only way we could build our project on such a short notice. 

The more funding we get : 

  • The more Human Rights leaders will be able to come to Kiev
  • The more connections we can build with Ukranian civil society
  • The more accurate our report will be
  • The more political and media targets our report will reach.

Please support the fight for Europe and democracy in the Ukraine.

EGAM : The European Grassroots Antiracist Movement (EGAM) gathers the main Human Rights NGOs from 30 countries in Europe in order to structure the fight for democracy and against racism, antisemitism, racial discrimination and genocide denial at a truly European level. 

EGAM has been following the events in the Ukraine very closely and sent a first delegation in December 2012 to meet, support and connect the leaders of Maidan to other European activists.

For 3 months, pro-democracy citizens have been demonstrating peacefuly on Maidan as well as in the rest of the Ukraine to defend their rights to democracy. 

In the last days, they are the victims of a violent repression that caused 25 dead people and hundreds of wounded. Half of Maidan in now occupied by the riot police. 

Pro-democracy citizens are now in a very tense and difficult situation. 

They need European support.

story:
Short Summary

We're a grassroots group, made up of pro-indy Catalans and Scots living in both nations. We feel it is important to give a voice to those of us who support freedom for our nations, because we wish to see Scotland and Catalonia governed by the people who care most about our future. And that's why we need to spread the word about our cause! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

With just £5 we can pay for leaflets or create online ads to reach people across the globe and raise awareness of our cause. Any donation will have a great impact!

 

The Impact

With your help we can reach thousands of people who probably don't know what's happening in Catalonia, and we will make them know the truth and know the repressive and fascist attitude of the Spanish Government.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

OK, so not everyone can afford to donate, but you can still help us by:

· Sharing this campaign with your relatives and friends

· Get out the word about the Catalan cause. Spread the word, join our Facebook group, "like" our Facebook page, follow us on Twitter, etc.

· Contributing to the debate! If you're a proud supporter of the democratic pro-independence movement you can attend demonstrations, talk to your family, friends and neighbours - don't be afraid to get the word out.

story:
Story of My Book

The Mindset of a Refugee: Understanding the Human Potential of Current and Former Refugees to Change Our Planet is about empowering refugees to help themselves, encouraging organizations to include refugees at the table of solution finding, and investing in refugees currently living in refugee camps, and also acknowledge the good comes from welcoming in refugees. 


My name is Joseph Minani and I am the author of The Mindset of a Refugee. I wrote this book because I lived the refugee experience in Camp Lukole, Tanzania after my family fled the great lakes region of east Africa from Burundi and Rwanda escaping a genocide.  After 12 years in the United States, there came a time when I reflected on my life as a whole and observed how far I have come and all the possibilities that lay ahead of me because my family and I were able to be resettled. I thought about the current conditions children and families are living in and their potential futures that lack options. What if I could tell that kid that it’s possible to thrive or that he or she has a potential that could change the world and themselves? What if I can convince you that these this community of people are worth supporting and these families can one day be your favorite neighbors?

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover what it means to be a refugee opposite to how the media portrays them. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for global citizenship in you. And then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help empower you, those around you, and help others help themselves.

In this book, you'll learn about the power of a mindset forged in adversity. In it I tell:

The story of my own journey coming to the United States. 

The story of Sandy Dang and her incredible strides from refugee to community leader. 

The stories of hope and the unique case of perseverance found in refugees

You will love this book if you believe that everyone deserves a right to life, freedom, and a future enriched with endless possibilities.

The Mindset of a Refugee, is a non-fiction book that speaks to organizational leaders and people who stand with refugees looking for ways to support refugees effectively or work with former or current refugees for the first time.

The Book - The Mindset of A Refugee

The book is written in 3 Parts....

Part 1 contains the introduction + chapters 1-3. The first chapter is about the history of refugees. From the early 1800’s refugees to the present day refugees crisis. In chapter two, readers will learn about the mindset after trauma and the potential it has to uplift people when given the right support. Chapter 3 is about why we should support refugees. You’ll learn about reciprocity and how helping refugees helps all of us.

Part 2 contains chapters 4-6. In this section, you will learn the incredible qualities of current and former refugees. You will learn about hope, compassion, courage, and perseverance from a unique perspective while learning how we should help refugees harness the power within and better themselves to better our world.

Part 3 contains the last three chapters. Here, you will learn how to support refugees, how to change your perspective on refugeeness, and the importance of investing in refugee mental health. You will hear stories from mental health providers and company leaders on the importance of implementing a middle grounding where organizations and refugee leaders work hand in hand, and essentially why refugees deserve a seat at the table.
 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 

The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in July, 2020

The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!

The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)

The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication

The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish in summer 2020

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
You will receive

A personally signed copy of my book when I publish

A personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book

Your name will appear in a Special Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)

Early access to the Introduction of my book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback

The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover

I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book

And more...

About the Author

Joseph Minani is brother to two sisters and three brothers. He saw the importance of education from a young age and acknowledged the sacrifices his parents made in order for him and his siblings to lead a better life. Joseph is awesome to have around and he leads by example. 

Writing is a way of clearing his mind and moving further in life. He felt the need to write this book due to the current challenges refugees face as their lives in the refugee camp is prolonged due to leaders around the world not accepting to take in more refugees. This is especially true in the US, a place he calls home after he and his family arrived as refugees  and given an opportunity for a better life and future. He is curious to see how people react to this new perspective of understanding refugees and how people will express their own thoughts on this topic.

Joseph is currently a college junior majoring in computer science with a minor in mathematics. He loves sports, in particular, soccer and basketball. In his spare time, he enjoys working out, listening to music from different cultures and genres, and acquiring new skills. 

For more information you can connect with Joseph on Instagram @_Joseph_Minani, on LinkedIn as Joseph Minani, on Twitter @JosephMinani2 or email him at Josephminani@fugeesAcademy.org

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #TheMindset and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Joseph Minani
story_txt:
Story of My Book
The Mindset of a Refugee: Understanding the Human Potential of Current and Former Refugees to Change Our Planet is about empowering refugees to help themselves, encouraging organizations to include refugees at the table of solution finding, and investing in refugees currently living in refugee camps, and also acknowledge the good comes from welcoming in refugees. 
My name is Joseph Minani and I am the author of The Mindset of a Refugee. I wrote this book because I lived the refugee experience in Camp Lukole, Tanzania after my family fled the great lakes region of east Africa from Burundi and Rwanda escaping a genocide.  After 12 years in the United States, there came a time when I reflected on my life as a whole and observed how far I have come and all the possibilities that lay ahead of me because my family and I were able to be resettled. I thought about the current conditions children and families are living in and their potential futures that lack options. What if I could tell that kid that it’s possible to thrive or that he or she has a potential that could change the world and themselves? What if I can convince you that these this community of people are worth supporting and these families can one day be your favorite neighbors?My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover what it means to be a refugee opposite to how the media portrays them. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for global citizenship in you. And then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help empower you, those around you, and help others help themselves.In this book, you'll learn about the power of a mindset forged in adversity. In it I tell:
The story of my own journey coming to the United States. 
The story of Sandy Dang and her incredible strides from refugee to community leader. 
The stories of hope and the unique case of perseverance found in refugees

story:
Why I am doing this...

It feels wrong and it makes me sad when I see homeless people, begging for money and food and sleeping on the street. I see people look the other way. Why? 

Can you help?

I want to try and raise $800. So if 80 people give $10 each I will hit my goal. And you will feel good, too. I will give the money to my school teacher who is helping me with this project. Then she will give it to one of the charities that works with the homeless people of Vancouver. 

You can make a difference

One person can make a difference and bring some happiness into someone else's life. And then another, and another, and another. So imagine if all of you reading this helped...what a HUGE difference that will make!

Maybe share with your friends?

It's easy. Just follow the steps. Thank you!

Ben

story:
Marissa Alexander's current fundraising campaign can be found HERE!

January 28, 2015 UPDATE: 

Marissa Alexander Released from Prison;

Supporters Celebrate, Demand FULL FREEDOM!

Supporters of Marissa Alexander in Jacksonville, across the US, and all around the world are overjoyed that she has been released from jail after serving 3 years behind bars for defending her life.  In 2010, Marissa Alexander, a black mother of three from Jacksonville, Florida, was forced to defend her life from a life-threatening attack by her estranged husband by firing a single warning shot that caused no injuries.  State Prosecutor Angela Corey prosecuted Marissa, pursuing a 60 year mandatory minimum sentence.  On November 24, 2014, Marissa accepted a plea deal that included time served of nearly 3 years in prison, 65 additional days in the Duval County jail, and 2 years of probation while under home detention.  January 27, 2015 marked the end of her time behind bars.

We are thrilled that Marissa will finally be reunited with her children, her family, and her community. Today’s hearing revealed that Marissa intends to attend school to become a paralegal and she is a wonderful mother to her children who urgently need her.  Amazingly, the State continued their campaign of punishment by trying to add two more years of probation on top of the two years of house detention included in the plea. Fortunately, they failed. Marissa and her family will need time to begin recovering from this arduous and traumatic experience. It’s been a long and painful journey and, though her release from jail is definitely a win -- no 60 years -- the journey of seeking ultimate freedom is not over.  Marissa will be forced to be on strict home detention while being under surveillance for two years.  This is by no means freedom in the sense we feel she deserves.  Our next agenda is to seek full restoration for Marissa and her family, including the expunging of her so-called criminal record, and a systemic transformation that prevents black women and all survivors of domestic violence from experiencing the hostile and brutal treatment from policing, prosecution, and prison systems that Marissa has endured. We will push for improved legislation and monitoring of systems that penalize victims of domestic violence who choose to save their lives by force. This is by no means a conclusion.  FMN's full press release is here, and we also recommend this reflection by Mariame Kaba, member of Chicago Alliance to Free Marissa Alexander.

We are filled with gratitude for the hundreds of people who have donated and organized fundraisers all around the world.  We want to be very clear: The reason Marissa is finally out of prison for good is directly because of your political and financial support.  Your donations were CRUCIAL in supporting her pro bono legal team to offer exceptional legal advocacy and your activism ensured that her case stayed in the public eye, which pressured Florida's politicians to pay attention.  Every one of us has a hand in this victory!  Thank you, thank you, thank you.

We're going to take a short break, but we'll be back with more specific thank you's and shout outs soon (there are so many!).  In the meantime, feel free to continue to donate to the CURRENT FUND and help Marissa Alexander cover the very expensive process of rebuilding her life.

Towards freedom, 

Free Marissa Now Mobilization Campaign

---

Marissa Alexander is an African American mother of three and survivor of domestic violence from Jacksonville, FL.  In 2010, she fired a warning shot upwards into a wall to defend herself from a life-threatening beating from her estranged husband. Despite the fact that Marissa caused no injuries and has no previous criminal record, and despite the fact that Florida’s self-defense law includes the right to “Stand Your Ground,” she was subsequently arrested, prosecuted, and sentenced to 20 years in prison.  She won an appeal, but was then re-prosecuted and threatened with a 60 year sentence.  She accepted a plea deal in November 2014 that included almost 3 years of time served in prison, 65 additional days in Duval County Jail, and 2 years of house detention while wearing and paying for an ankle surveillance monitor.  On January 27, 2015, Marissa was finally released from jail and reunited with her family.  Free Marissa Now continues to demand her full freedom.

FULL ACQUITTAL: A Movement Behind The Trial

Free Marissa Now, an alliance of organizers and thousands of people all around the world, have been organizing for Marissa's freedom from prison and intend to keep going until she is free.  Because State Attorney Angela Corey refuses to drop the case against Marissa Alexander, continuing a pattern of unjust targeting and prosecution, our movement turns to supporting Marissa, her family, and her legal team in winning her full freedom.

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

This fundraiser is accountable to Marissa Alexander and her family.  All proceeds from this fundraiser go to the Marissa Alexander Legal Defense Fund which is administered by Marissa's family on her behalf. You can find the link to this fundraiser on the family's website:http://justiceformarissa.blogspot.com/.

Contact us at freemarissanow@gmail.com if you have questions.

THANK YOU!

Marissa's supporters are the greatest!  Every step of the way, you have shown up and given deep support and love.  Your donation is just one more way that you give life to the movement to free Marissa and highlight the need to support all survivors who have been criminalized while trying to navigate the conditions of violence.  Thank you so much for your donation!

PS:

If you want to send a donation via check, please make the check out to:

Global Alliance, Inc.
For: The Marissa Alexander Legal Defense Fund

Mail to:

Global Alliance, Inc.
P.O. Box 290956
Columbia, SC 29229

But please e-mail a note to us at freemarissanow@gmail.com so we can include your donation in our fundraising total!
