story:
This fundraiser is for humanitarian relief and development. If you want to donate to Matthew VanDyke's organization Sons of Liberty International, which operates on a non-profit model in order to provide free military consulting and training to communities fighting terrorists, insurgents, and oppressive regimes (and which relies entirely on contributions for funding to provide these services) please visit SonsOfLibertyInternational.com.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Update: Thanks to your donations, over 6,000 Christmas gifts in 1,200 gift bags were given to 1,045 Assyrian families (over 3,500 children!) in the Ashti 2 refugee camp in Ankawa, Iraq.

Click here for details and dozens of great photographs!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(What follows is the text from the 2015 fundraiser)


Last year's fundraiser was so successful that we're doing it again this year!

And with a twist. Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke will each match all donations to this fundraiser up to $1,000 each! Your donation can have triple the impact!
For example, if you give $50, Sons of Liberty International will give $50, and Matthew VanDyke will give $50, making your $50 donation into $150. Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke will continue matching donations until they each reach $1,000 donated, meaning that the first $1,000 donated this year by the public will result in $3,000 total being donated!


In 2014, this fundraiser helped purchase 2,000 Christmas presents for 1,500 Assyrian Iraqi Christian children in the Nineveh Plain region of Iraq.


This year, we're doing it again. 

This has been a very difficult year for many of Iraq's Christian children, having become refugees in their own country after losing their homes to ISIS last year.

Help us give them a Christmas they'll never forget, and that will bring them some happiness this holiday season.


The details:

-Last year's fundraiser has raised $17,392 as of 11/17/2015, and was turned into an IndieGoGo InDemand campaign to allow it to continue each year. That means the starting point for this year's fundraiser is $17,392.

- Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke are each matching all donations until $1,000 has been donated by the public (at which time $1,000 will have been donated by Sons of Liberty International and $1,000 will have been donated by Matthew VanDyke, making the total raised $1,000+$1,000+$1,000=$3,000 (which will show as $20,392 on this InDemand fundraiser).

- Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke will each match the first $1,000 in donations (these will be matched to the total outside of IndieGoGo so that more funds go towards the cause and less towards credit card and other fees)

- 100% of the funds will go towards helping Christians in Iraq. None of the funds will be used for overhead, travel, etc.

- Most of the funds will be used for Christmas presents for Assyrian Iraqi Christian children. We are saying most instead of all because last year the Assyrian Iraqi Christian activists we worked with in Iraq, in the spirit of Christmas, wanted to help 6 Yazidi families who needed assistance, so some of the funds were used to purchase enough food supplies to feed the families for months. We anticipate that in the spirit of giving, a similar initiative by Assyrian Iraqi Christian activists might be undertaken, or that an emergency in Iraq could require some funds to be used to address a critical need of the Assyrian Iraqi Christian refugees.


2014 fundraiser:

Last year's fundraiser was an incredible success, raising over $12,000 during the regular IndieGoGo fundraiser and thousands of dollars more as an IndieGoGo InDemand campaign afterwards, reaching a total of $17,392 as of 11/17/2015 when the fundraiser for Christmas 2015 was launched.

Your donated funds made an incredible impact for the Christians of Iraq:

- Helped purchase 2,000 Christmas presents for 1,500 Assyrian Iraqi Christian children

- Helped purchase enough food to feed 6 impoverished Yazidi families for months

- Purchased a video projector for Iraqi Christian children and families to watch videos and movies together

Sons of Liberty International founder Matthew VanDyke watching a Christmas program with Assyrian children in Al Qosh, Iraq in 2014

Please give generously this year and we'll help make Christmas 2015 a time of joy and happiness for children who are innocent victims of ISIS.

About Assyrian Iraqi Christians: The Assyrian people of Iraq are the original inhabitants of the country, with northern Iraq as their ancestral homeland dating back over 4,000 years. The Assyrians converted to Christianity in the early days of the faith, and their churches and holy sites are among the oldest in Christianity. They speak a modern version of Aramaic, the same language as Jesus. Assyrians have been persecuted in Iraq for years and many have fled, with the population going from 1.2 million Assyrians in Iraq in 2003 to approximately 300,000 before ISIS attacked. Over 100,000 have lost their homes and lands to ISIS and many now live as refugees (internally displaced persons) in their own country, hoping to one day return to their homes.

About Sons of Liberty International: Sons of Liberty International (SOLI) is an organization that provides free advising, training, and supplies to forces fighting against ISIS. In 2014-2015 SOLI trained over 300 Assyrian Iraqi Christians to fight against ISIS and will expand operations in the coming months. Visit www.sonsoflibertyinternational.com to learn more.

About Matthew VanDyke: Matthew VanDyke is an international security analyst, former filmmaker, and founder of Sons of Liberty International. He appears regularly in the media as an analyst/commentator, including on FOX News and MSNBC. Visit www.matthewvandyke.com to learn more.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------
(What follows is the text from the 2014 fundraiser)

In June there were 30,000 Christians in Mosul, Iraq. Today, there are 0.

Given an ultimatum by the insurgent group ISIS to convert or die, one of the oldest Christian communities in the world has been wiped out as they were forced to flee, some with only the clothes they were wearing.

Women even had crucifixes torn from their necks as they fled.

My name is Matthew VanDyke. I am an American filmmaker, international security analyst, and combat veteran of the 2011 Libyan Revolution known for my documentary films Not Anymore: A Story of Revolution about the war in Syria and Point and Shoot about my experiences fighting in Libya.

I lived in Iraq for much of 2008-2010, during some of the period covered in Point and Shoot. During this time I worked as an English teacher, war correspondent, documentary filmmaker, and in the import business. I explored various parts of Iraq by motorcycle during those years, getting to know many Iraqis from a wide variety of backgrounds and regions of the country.

In 2014 I will return to Iraq and oversee the delivery of aid to Iraqi Christians who have been forced from their homes by ISIS (the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, also known as ISIL or IS). ISIS is an insurgent group that broke away from Al Qaeda in 2014 and has waged a campaign of extreme brutality against both Syrians and Iraqis. In addition, the group is responsible for the kidnappings of several international journalists, including personal friends of mine.

These are all innocents who have had their lives destroyed by the militant radicals of ISIS, many of whom are not even from Syria and Iraq but instead foreign radicals who have come to impose their will on a terrified population.

Mosul, Iraq is home to one of the oldest Christian communities in the world, dating back to the first few centuries of the religion. In June, 2014 ISIS invaded Mosul, capturing the city and making it the capital of their declared Islamic State.

Much as Jews were forced to wear the Star of David by Nazis during the holocaust, ISIS began painting the letter "N" for "Nasrani” or Nazarene (Christian in Arabic) on the homes of Christians.

In July, 2014 ISIS ordered all Christians to convert to Islam or be killed. A few converted to protect their families, but most fled the city.

As they fled, many were robbed of everything they had taken with them at the ISIS checkpoints around the city, leaving them with just the clothes on their backs. The homes and businesses they had left behind were looted and seized.

They have lost everything.

The goal is to raise $12,000, a figure symbolically chosen because of its significance in Christianity (12 disciples, 12 tribes of Israel, and more).


What Is Needed & What You Get


100% OF THE FUNDS RAISED WILL GO TO HELP CHRISTIANS IN IRAQ.

I will not be using -any- of the funds for my travel or other expenses while delivering this aid.

All of the funds raised through IndieGoGo will benefit Christians in Iraq, with approximately 90% used for direct aid and projects on the ground and no more than 10% for increasing awareness of the issue and promoting the fundraiser to raise more money for the cause.

The funds you donate won't be lost to travel and overhead expenses like with so many fundraisers and charitable organizations that can spend as much as 30% or more on such expenses.

This is a unique opportunity to be part of a desperately needed relief effort that will be directly managed by someone with extensive experience and contacts in Iraq and the region. You can have complete confidence that your donations will go directly to purchasing and distributing aid, as I will personally oversee this process in Iraq. I will be there to ensure that your donations are used properly, effectively, and ethically.

The Impact

The funds will ideally be used to implement as many long-lasting, sustainable aid projects as possible, dependent on the amount raised and the situation encountered on the ground. These may include such possibilities as new water wells (ISIS has cut off water to some of the Christian villages around Mosul), constructing a community bakery for refugee families, helping Christian shopkeepers who lost everything reopen in their place of resettlement, or funding the expansion of churches to accommodate the Christian refugees. Funds may also be used for more immediate relief, including the purchase of materials for schoolchildren, clothing and other necessities for displaced families and individuals, and toys for refugee children.

The needs of the Christian refugees are substantial. The only reason for not stating a specific project for the funds at this time is that far too often people are helped in ways that aren't needed (sending cargo containers of clothes when another organization has already provided them with enough) or even in ways that are detrimental (when that donated clothing upsets the local economy and causes tailors to close shop).

Therefore, in the best interest of those being helped, the funds will be committed to projects once I am on the ground in Iraq and able to personally assess, with the help of my extensive network of contacts, what is needed and determine the most effective way to implement the projects.

I have years of experience in Iraq, particularly in this northern region of the country around Mosul (and some experience inside Mosul as well). I have the people on the ground who can do this the right way and help ensure that the money goes where it is needed. I will provide photographs and hopefully some video as well of how your donations were used so you can see the impact your contributions have made on specific individuals whose lives you can help change forever.

Risks & Challenges

This is a low-risk fundraiser for donors because I'm putting my name and reputation on the line in this effort and as a public figure am easily held accountable for the outcome.

For me it is high-risk as I will face the threat of being kidnapped or killed by ISIS. I am well-known to ISIS because of my military service in Libya and various work I have done for the revolution in Syria over the years. My status as a former combatant in Libya and a current activist and adviser in Syria has dramatically increased the risks I face when working in the region in general, but particularly in countries like Iraq where ISIS has a strong presence.

Regardless of the challenges, I will not be deterred from this mission. The expulsion of Christians from Mosul, Iraq represents a grave injustice that has not only horrified Christians like myself, but also most Muslims around the world because this treatment of Christians violates their faith as well.

The Christians of Mosul are truly suffering innocents and I call on people of all faiths to support this fundraiser to provide the relief that they desperately need.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I hope that in addition to making a contribution to this fundraiser that you will take a few moments to promote it through social media (Facebook, Twitter, Google+, LinkedIn, Reddit, etc.) using the Indiegogo share tools or other methods.

    Donations collected from churches and community organizations are also welcome, and of course please speak about and promote this fundraiser at your own worship services and events.

    Some articles about ISIS persecuting Christians in Iraq

    ISIS Robs Christians Fleeing Its Edict in Mosul: Convert, Leave, or Die
    ISIS to Christians in Mosul: Leave, Convert to Islam or Die

    Last remaining Christians flee Iraq's Mosul
story_txt:
This fundraiser is for humanitarian relief and development. If you want to donate to Matthew VanDyke's organization Sons of Liberty International, which operates on a non-profit model in order to provide free military consulting and training to communities fighting terrorists, insurgents, and oppressive regimes (and which relies entirely on contributions for funding to provide these services) please visit SonsOfLibertyInternational.com.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Update: Thanks to your donations, over 6,000 Christmas gifts in 1,200 gift bags were given to 1,045 Assyrian families (over 3,500 children!) in the Ashti 2 refugee camp in Ankawa, Iraq.

Click here for details and dozens of great photographs!
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(What follows is the text from the 2015 fundraiser)

Last year's fundraiser was so successful that we're doing it again this year!

And with a twist. Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke will each match all donations to this fundraiser up to $1,000 each! Your donation can have triple the impact!
For example, if you give $50, Sons of Liberty International will give $50, and Matthew VanDyke will give $50, making your $50 donation into $150. Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke will continue matching donations until they each reach $1,000 donated, meaning that the first $1,000 donated this year by the public will result in $3,000 total being donated!


In 2014, this fundraiser helped purchase 2,000 Christmas presents for 1,500 Assyrian Iraqi Christian children in the Nineveh Plain region of Iraq.



This year, we're doing it again. 
This has been a very difficult year for many of Iraq's Christian children, having become refugees in their own country after losing their homes to ISIS last year.
Help us give them a Christmas they'll never forget, and that will bring them some happiness this holiday season.


The details:
-Last year's fundraiser has raised $17,392 as of 11/17/2015, and was turned into an IndieGoGo InDemand campaign to allow it to continue each year. That means the starting point for this year's fundraiser is $17,392.
- Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke are each matching all donations until $1,000 has been donated by the public (at which time $1,000 will have been donated by Sons of Liberty International and $1,000 will have been donated by Matthew VanDyke, making the total raised $1,000+$1,000+$1,000=$3,000 (which will show as $20,392 on this InDemand fundraiser).
- Sons of Liberty International and Matthew VanDyke will each match the first $1,000 in donations (these will be matched to the total outside of IndieGoGo so that more funds go towards the cause and less towards credit card and other fees)
- 100% of the funds will go towards helping Christians in Iraq. None of the funds will be used for overhead, travel, etc.
- Most of the funds will be used for Christmas presents for Assyrian Iraqi Christian children. We are saying most instead of all because last year the Assyrian Iraqi Christian activists we worked with in Iraq, in the spirit of Christmas, wanted to help 6 Yazidi families who needed assistance, so some of the funds were used to purchase enough food supplies to feed the families for months. We anticipate that in the spirit of giving, a similar initiative by Assyrian Iraqi Christian activists might be undertaken, or that an emergency in Iraq could require some funds to be used to address a critical need of the Assyrian Iraqi Christian refugees.


2014 fundraiser:
Last year's fundraiser was an incredible success, raising over $12,000 during the regular IndieGoGo fundraiser and thousands of dollars more as an IndieGoGo InDemand campaign afterwards, reaching a total of $17,392 as of 11/17/2015 when the fundraiser for Christmas 2015 was launched.
Your donated funds made an incredible impact for the Christians of Iraq:
- Helped purchase 2,000 Christmas presents for 1,500 Assyrian Iraqi Christian children
- Helped purchase enough food to feed 6 impoverished Yazidi families for months
- Purchased a video projector for Iraqi Christian children and families to watch videos and movies together





Sons of Liberty International founder Matthew VanDyke watching a Christmas program with Assyrian children in Al Qosh, Iraq in 2014

Please give generously this year and we'll help make Christmas 2015 a time of joy and happiness for children who are innocent victims of ISIS.

About Assyrian Iraqi Christians: The Assyrian people of Iraq are the original inhabitants of the country, with northern Iraq as their ancestral homeland dating back over 4,000 years. The Assyrians converted to Christianity in the early days of the faith, and their churches and holy sites are among the oldest in Christianity. They speak a modern version of Aramaic, the same language as Jesus. Assyrians have been persecuted in Iraq for years and many have fled, with the population going from 1.2 million Assyrians in Iraq in 2003 to approximately 300,000 before ISIS attacked. Over 100,000 have lost their homes and lands to ISIS and many now live as refugees (internally displaced persons) in their own country, hoping to one day return to their homes.
About Sons of Liberty International: Sons of Liberty International (SOLI) is an organization that provides free advising, training, and supplies to forces fighting against ISIS. In 2014-2015 SOLI trained over 300 Assyrian Iraqi Christians to fight against ISIS and will expand operations in the coming months. Visit www.sonsoflibertyinternational.com to learn more.
About Matthew VanDyke: Matthew VanDyke is an international security analyst, former filmmaker, and founder of Sons of Liberty International. He appears regularly in the media as an analyst/commentator, including on FOX News and MSNBC. Visit www.matthewvandyke.com to learn more.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------
(What follows is the text from the 2014 fundraiser)
In June there were 30,000 Christians in Mosul, Iraq. Today, there are 0.

Given an ultimatum by the insurgent group ISIS to convert or die, one of the oldest Christian communities in the world has been wiped out as they were forced to flee, some with only the clothes they were wearing.
Women even had crucifixes torn from their necks as they fled.
My name is Matthew VanDyke. I am an American filmmaker, international security analyst, and combat veteran of the 2011 Libyan Revolution known for my documentary films Not Anymore: A Story of Revolution about the war in Syria and Point and Shoot about my experiences fighting in Libya.
I lived in Iraq for much of 2008-2010, during some of the period covered in Point and Shoot. During this time I worked as an English teacher, war correspondent, documentary filmmaker, and in the import business. I explored various parts of Iraq by motorcycle during those years, getting to know many Iraqis from a wide variety of backgrounds and regions of the country.
In 2014 I will return to Iraq and oversee the delivery of aid to Iraqi Christians who have been forced from their homes by ISIS (the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, also known as ISIL or IS). ISIS is an insurgent group that broke away from Al Qaeda in 2014 and has waged a campaign of extreme brutality against both Syrians and Iraqis. In addition, the group is responsible for the kidnappings of several international journalists, including personal friends of mine.
These are all innocents who have had their lives destroyed by the militant radicals of ISIS, many of whom are not even from Syria and Iraq but instead foreign radicals who have come to impose their will on a terrified population.
Mosul, Iraq is home to one of the oldest Christian communities in the world, dating back to the first few centuries of the religion. In June, 2014 ISIS invaded Mosul, capturing the city and making it the capital of their declared Islamic State.
Much as Jews were forced to wear the Star of David by Nazis during the holocaust, ISIS began painting the letter "N" for "Nasrani” or Nazarene (Christian in Arabic) on the homes of Christians.
In July, 2014 ISIS ordered all Christians to convert to Islam or be killed. A few converted to protect their families, but most fled the city.
As they fled, many were robbed of everything they had taken with them at the ISIS checkpoints around the city, leaving them with just the clothes on their backs. The homes and businesses they had left behind were looted and seized.
They have lost everything.
The goal is to raise $12,000, a figure symbolically chosen because of its significance in Christianity (12 disciples, 12 tribes of Israel, and more).

story:
DEAR LONELY HEARTS,

 

let's take this chance of social distancing and create a new way of demonstration and showing the need of responsibility to do something together.

The idea is simple:

1: We are creating T-shirts. 

2: You can buy these T-shirts.

The special part:

1: By buying a shirt, your money will help to raise money for sea-watch.org

2: By wearing the shirt, you show solidarity and be part of a collective moment.

 

Since corona made us performing distance as a way of care, it’s becoming more difficult to be solidary and to organize solidarity. Of course, social distancing is one of the solutions to avoid the spread of the coronavirus, but as a consequence of that, demonstration and other social events to raise awareness or money are cancelled and not allowed to take place.

In the same moment the corona-pandemic take such a big space and place in the media, some important things lost their awareness:

For example the situation of more than 20.000 refugees, stuck in camps at Europe's border, which are made for 3000 people. Who is going to take care and do something for them, who are in need and in danger right now. A danger, which cannot be compared with the privilege of being able to stay at home and wash our hands.

 

Because of the current situation, we want to help https://sea-watch.org  „The organization provides emergency relief capacities, demands and pushes for rescue operations by the European institutions and stands up publicly for legal escape routes. They are politically and religiously independent and are financed solely through donations.“ (retrieved from their website)

We came up with an idea to collect donations, to support refugees in the camps at borders of Europe, where actually human rights are being ignored and people are under violence and in great danger. But it’s not just about private donations, its about a collective moment:

The shirts are created by the simple and beautiful structure of the „LONELY HEARTS GROUP“. Its about wearing solidarity as a sign of matter. The first shirt we made just saying ONE LONELY HEART. The next person ordering a shirt, will wear a shirt saying „TWO LONELY HEARTS“. The third one „THREE LONELY HEARTS“ and so on. The more people order shirts, the more money we can collect, the more people will be connected by the shirts. And the number of lonely hearts will raise as a symbol of solidarity and caring.

For minimizing cost (money and climate) we are using second-hand shirts. So we just need 5€ to make a shirt for and send it to you. The rest of your money will directly go to sea-watch e.V.

Of course we want to use the capitalist system here, because yes, we all live in it and yes, especially in these situations money can save lives. But also we want to try not reproducing capitalist pressure on individuals. So there is no defined prize for the shirts. If you buy a shirt for x€ we will donate (x-5)€. We would suggest to start at 10€, but feel free to ask yourself how much you can or want to give and choose one of the options. And in case you’re lost with anticapitalistic self-responsibilty: 

It’s a beautiful shirt and it’s 25€, Honey. 

On this site you can only pay by credit card. If you wanna use PayPal follow this link https://www.paypal.me/TShirtsForSolidatity?loca... and the instructions in the caption. In any other case, please contact us (showsolidarity@gmail.com) and we will find a way.

Everyone, also feeling lonely about the current situation is welcome to join THE GROUP OF LONELY HEARTS, by buying a t-shirt and the raised money will go to foundations, who are at the moment doing their best to help refugees. 

You can also help by sharing our project, order shirts for friends and family, sign petitions (https://www.change.org/p/alle-menschen-leavenoo...) or contact us to organize and share ideas and thoughts.

story:
The Rise to Power

1. Get you to like me

2. Say a bunch of stuff you agree with

3. Use the $1,000 and invest into World Domination stuff

4. Dominate the World 

5. Have a mental breakdown due to the pressure of being The World Dominator

6. Seclude oneself to study isolationism in the Black Forest

7. Eat the ham

8. Save the Glip Glops

9. Return to glory 

10. Battle at KOTD's World Domination in Los Angeles

story: Daron will be traveling to Haiti with an East River Church group from Hillsboro, OR. Daron has made three previous trips to Haiti and will be continuing projects that have been extremely beneficial to the people of Haiti. On this trip the group plans on continuing to work on structural damage to two different orphanages. This will help the orphanage remain safe and usable for the residents. As a general contractor Daron is very knowledgable with construction and his help is highly regarded.

story: This church needs lots of repairs doing to it, re-plastering, damp, heating, and toilets including disabled toilets, the church has always fed the poor, needy and homeless but to continue doing this it needs a new kitchen, new toilets, the church lets the Hull Homeless Outreach use its kitchen, but as of Wednesday 11 March 2015 the council's environmental health have stopped them using it, so for now over 50 homeless are being deprived of a hot meal twice a week. Please help in any way you can.
